Can her own words be trusted?<br /><br />I loved that we kept learning things as Christine did. We were in the dark and guessing just as much as she is. Is she making things up? Is it all just a misunderstanding? Can she trust Ben? Can she trust the Dr? There a lot of twists and turns that kept me guessing. I kept rooting for Christine to find the truth about herself.<br /><br />The premise of the novel sucks you into the narrative and you will demand answers! What could simply have been a silly gimmick is bolstered by great characters and intrigue that does not end!
B004Y1USV2|5.0|By 2009, I had written Yes off as a sad caricature of itself, nothing but a tribute band that had not made a fantastic album in over 20 years.  In 1981 I had written Yes off as done.  In 1989 I believed the 8 member fratricide was the death knell of the band.  Then, I thought Union's terrible production and apparent apathy from the members sounded the death knell.  Each time I wrote the band off, it came back to life and surprised me.  I should have known better this time around.  Never, never write off Yes.  Never, never be surprised at where the journey will take them, along with their fans.  There appears to be more buzz about this album than anything the band has done since 1991's lackluster Union lp.  Sales on Amazon appear to be unbelievably high;  the forums and chat rooms are ablaze; even Rolling Stone had an interesting piece about the new project (who would have thunk that!)    When I review albums, I look for four qualities: 1) strong musical material (including lyrics); 2) strong musicianship; 3) strong production and sound engineering; and 4) a consistent, even flowing listen from beginning to end.  Fly From Here ticks all the right boxes.  Hence, I can easily give it a five star review.    The material is melodic, interesting, and bridges nicely within songs and between songs; it has a nice pop sensibility without being \\"poppish\\".  It has a nice prog sensibility without being \\"progissh\\".  It has drama, mystical elements, emotional highs, color and, it is just a downright FUN listen.      The musicianship is stellar (although White is a bit subdued, not the power beast he was in the 70s and 80s).  Howe's and Squire's performance put a smile on my face.  I love Downes keyboard work.  And, I enjoy David's voice... it is not a Jon copy, nor a Horn copy, although, to my ear, it has elements closer to Horn than Anderson.      What can I say about the production??  In short, it is outstanding!  Horn is a dynamo in the studio.  The best Yes albums were produced by Eddy Offord and Trevor Horn.  These two producers understand the band better than, I believe, band members understand each other, and Yes as a whole.  Thus, this is easily the best produced album since the early Rabin Yes years.    The listen is a pleasure from beginning through middle, to the final note.  No fillers, no material or questionable production to worry about.  The first few bars of Squire's \\"The Man You Always Wanted Me to Be\\" had me a bit worried; and, I believe, under any other producer, would have come off as a dud.  But a full listen eased my concerns.  It is catchy, poppy, and well crafted without being drippy or sappy.    I can't understand why the \\"no Jon, no Yes\\" crowd cannot just enjoy the band for what it is now!  And now, the band is better on vinyl (so to speak) than it has been in more than 20 years.  I must admit, I miss hearing Jon's voice in the mix, and yet I do not miss it.  This album could have never been crafted with Jon in the ranks.  Drama could never have been crafted with Jon in the ranks.  I am mighty thankful for Drama and Fly From Here; the Yes catalogue would not be complete without these two stellar albums.    How does Fly From Here stand against the Yes albums all Yes fans can agree are the very best (The Yes Album, Fragile, Close to the Edge)?  Only time will tell.  Fly From Here is a very different album from those early works.  The current band is very different, in membership, in age, in life.  And I am happy with this... for life goes on.  Yes does not have to make or match another Fragile (my favorite Yes work) to satisfy me.  However, the band does need to offer more than it did on Union, Keys, Open Your Eyes, and Magnification (my least favorite Yes works).  Fly From Here is head and shoulders above those mediocre efforts.  Once again, I have learned the lesson to never write this band off.  Just when you think they are goners, they will surprise you!

B00005JKGO|5.0|I still recall my first couple viewings of La Dolce Vita. I was always unsure exactly what I thought of this peek into the lives of the rich and beautiful... and why anyone would want to make a movie about it (at the time this film was produced). But Fellini was all about examining life, and he didn't consider class in the process.     When I finally bought \\"Vita\\", in an effort to put together a decent collection of Italian films, I watched it as an examination of life... nothing more or less. Watching in the manner in which Fellini went on record to explain what motivated him to produce films helped. I actually laugh at scenes I had little reaction to before, and I find myself nodding or shaking my head --knowingly-- at others.    More than a film about the rich and beautiful, this is a film about the things with which we want to and/or fill our lives. Because the film has no clear narrative (and life doesn't pass with carefully planned narrative), the audience is bombarded with the unquenchable \\"want/desire\\" of the protagonist and his crowd. Every once in while we're reminded of the way the other half lives, and what they deem important. With each \\"reminder\\", I find \\"The Sweet/Good Life\\" makes my skin crawl just a little more. And I consider how so much of modern society is more like the haves than the have nots.    If you aren't familiar with this cinematic gem, there has been a lot of debate regarding religious under/overtones and numerology in the film. Those debates don't interest me much.    Finally, the digital transfer of \\"Dolce\\" is gorgeous. I've read about the version with the subtitles on the actual picture. The version I have doesn't suffer from any of that. I'm looking forward to future viewings/examinations AND the revelations about my life I'll realize through them.

B004EPYZUI|4.0|I'll break down my review into the following sections:  1. Initial thoughts on movie  2. Video, Audio Quality  3. Special Features    1. I initially heard a ton of bad reviews about this movie; most people were disappointed with the execution considering all the hype. I never saw the movie in a  theater, but rather rented it on blu-ray and then decided to buy it, especially when I found out that the Two-Disc Extended Edition had an R-rated version of the film that had an additional ~20 minutes. I also wanted to see the extra features. As far as the film goes, it's a got a pretty simple story that is easy to follow, a linear plot (for the most part), and plenty of visually impressive effects, typical of Zack Snyder. The few complaints that I have about the film itself is that the characters are not very well developed (which is improved slightly in the extended version), and some of the more visually impressive scenes are not well integrated into the story and seem more like they were incorporated as a means of showing off the capabilities of CG. 7/10 in this aspect.    2. In regards to the actual video and audio quality, the blu-ray transfer was excellent and the video quality, even for blu-ray is pretty incredible. I cannot imagine watching this film is anything less than full 1080p high-resolution. The audio is synced well and complements the stunning visual effects well throughout the film. Multiple coding options are available on the disc, so it can be optimized for any home theater setup. 9/10 here.    3. The special features, while not incredibly extensive, make a huge difference when choosing to rent or buy this film. The extended version does not dramatically change the quality of the film, but does provide a little more time for character development without interrupting the flow of the narrative. A relatively unique feature is \\"Maximum Movie Mode\\" which is also found on Watchmen and is basically a visual commentary by Director Zack Snyder. If you are intothe film-making process, this alone makes this product worth buying. There are a lot of photo galleries and stills that I don't find very interesting, but overall the special features are top notch. 7/10 for these.

Don't you dare put that hat on and then we will be stuck with LeBouf as the new Indy!!!\\"  Luckily at the last second Indy snatches it out of his hands and puts it back on. Whew, close one!    Overall Lucas and Spielberg didn't do too badly here. The cast is pretty deep and the story is classic Indian Jones with its share of action, intrigue, and wit. The biggest problem comes from the part of the title that's called \\"Indiana Jones.\\" When people saw that they immediately got their hopes way too high. 3.5 stars.

B0036TGSIK|2.0|I heard mostly good things about Easy A, but after viewing, I am a bit astonished by the many favorable reviews, especially considering how relatively commonplace this comedy is. Easy A tells the story of one high school girl who uses a rumor of having sex to boost her popularity. She finds that things quickly get out of hand, and she tries to protect her image, keep her friendship, and more importantly try to find out who she is amidst all the high school mayhem and gossip.  The film attempts to be satirical in some ways and genuine in others, but there are missed opportunities to make it a funny, unique movie. Instead, there is a run of the mill approach to direction, characterization and plot, and it suffers from being rather false .     Easy A is surprisingly mediocre, its presentation phony and superficial, using caricatures rather than characters to sell its plot, with its story and lesson being somewhat petty.  Indicative of Hollywood high school land, we have prototype antagonists, cardboard to the max, whose sole purpose is to fling degrading insults at the protagonist. The film further shows its immature approach by using Christians as the major antagonists as a parallel to Hawthorne's hypocritical Puritans (in The Scarlet Letter). (Apparently Christians are fair game as being portrayed as disingenuous in Hollywood...Where are the Hollywood PC police when you really need them?) Olive's parents are ridiculously unbelievable, quite annoying, having apparently been transplanted directly from the set of Juno to Easy A, as their super duper hip, cool demeanor towards anything and everything Olive has to throw at them doesn't faze them a bit. (That scene with Olive and her mom talking and her mom describing her sexual exploits...ummm..yeah, right, like THAT would ever happen). Meanwhile, Olive's friend Rhiannon (Alyson Michalka) is the biggest nitwit of them all, and I'm still trying to figure out how they were \\"friends\\" in the first place. Not only was their friendship shallow and insincere, but it was pretty much unnecessary to the movie's plot other than bringing in some contrived conflict. And, as a whole, the movie pretty much reeked of phoniness trying to embody some serious life lesson, but really comes across hallow to the core. Easy A sells itself as some modern rehashing of Hawthorne's The Scarlet Letter, but it is a very flimsy, superficial one at that. It's too bad, because Easy A could have been a clever satire.     The one saving grace of Easy A is Emma Stone. While I liked Emma Stone's performance, I didn't think the script (or its lack of originality) did her any justice, or gave her much to work with. Her character Olive, however, does have some depth (unlike virtually every other character), but everything about the whole fake sex thing seemed so dumb and contrived. (Are all the students, counselors, teachers and principle at this school that gullible, dense, and dim-witted? I guess so.)  Still, I liked her better in The Rocker and Zombieland, where her sarcastic, witty demeanor and acting ability shines, and she does not have to carry a film.     Easy A is pretty the stuff of your standard Hollywood tripe. Any references to John Hughes'80s films should be left at the door.

B002KSPKRS|4.0|At first, I always wanted a wireless surround sound system for my room. As I began searching, I found that the options were pretty limited, and the costs were very high. I knew I could never put in a wired system, since I do not have the knowledge and my parents would probably kill me. Then I remembered my cousin had Turtle Beaches for his Xbox 360. When I began to search I realized this was the best solution for me, since it provided the surround sound system effect. Upon researching for about a week and asking lots of people's opinion I kept on getting pointed to the X41. After a day or two of thinking, I made the leap and purchased the X41 as opposed to the X31.<br /><br />Out of the box, the headphones appear rather cheap. They are made mostly of plastic and so I do not know how long they will last. The headphones come with a receiver, which connects to a digital output on the Xbox 360 and also has a USB connector which connects to the 360 as well (this is actually where the receiver gets its power supply from). From the directions, it appears they do not have information on the Xbox 360 Slim which I have. There is no input for the Xbox 360 Slim on the other end of the RCA cables. Instead, you will find one near the cable which connects into your power supply. After that, setup was pretty much a breeze. The manual warns that interference can occur with a Wireless N network (which I have) however, I do not have that problem.<br /><br />For Gaming:<br />After finally getting everything going, I decided to play the most recent Grand Theft Auto. At first, I played it for about 5 minutes with no headphones, and then I put them on. The change was like night and day. You can hear peoples footsteps getting closer and closer from the distance. You know a car is about to pass you because you could hear it turn down the street from behind you. There is a helicopter coming from the right and quickly flying over to your left. Someone nearby gets into a car accident and you can hear the awful crush of metal. It was just amazing. Then I decided to pull out some guns...which is a bad idea when the volume is maxed. It was LOUD and intense, especially with guns such as the AK47, but it was awesome. I decided to then take out a rocket launcher and hit a nearby car. The explosion was ridiculous and the ringing was intense. I would also recommend getting really nice cars and driving them fast, since the roar of the engine makes you feel like your there. I then switched to many other games, such as Call of duty, which was also great since you could hear where people were coming from while playing online. Overall, a great experience.<br /><br />For Music:<br />Then I thought, wouldn't it be nice to hook this up to my iPod? Unfortunately, this is not completely possible. First off, the jacks for the headphones are mini-jacks, so they do not fit headphone jacks. I knew there are mini-jack to headphone jack cables, so I did alittle research online and then found that they will not work. The headphones must be operating with the receiver and cannot be used independently. So you will not be able to just listen to your music on these headphones outside of the room the receiver is in. What you will need is a cable with the white and red RCA males and then a headphone jack connection on the other end. Plug the RCA's into the receiver and the other end into your iPod or whatever, and bingo. The receiver will then wirelessly send music to your X41. The quality here is pretty good. However, I have had Bose headphones which cost about the same as this headset and the Bose are much better. These headphones just don't offer the same amount of bass (even with the bass booster, which is still a very nice feature). But don't get me wrong, the sound quality is very good and is probably better than any other earbuds that you have. I just think that this headset wasn't exactly made for this purpose to begin with.<br /><br />For Movies:<br />After I was thinking about music, I then drifted into the thought of movies. I know that the majority of movies now are in Dolby digital surround sound, so these headphones would be perfect for it. I own a relatively new 1080i Vizio Razor which unforunately has about the worse speakers known to man. Anyway, I also have a laptop with a built in Blu-ray player and HDMI input. So typically, I just connect my laptop using HDMI into my TV and use my laptop as basically a Blu-ray player. This works very well actually, and the quality is amazing. Then I connected the digital cable from the receiver of the X41 directly to a digital port in my TV. I learned that this actually allows me to listen to movies in full Dolby surround sound and I can also listen to any TV channel (even when the TV is set to mute, since the audio is independent - which is awesome). So then I popped in a Blu-ray Harry Potter to my laptop and was off. All I can say is, WOW. I think these were made more for movies than for the Xbox. I could hear EVERYTHING from all different angles. Up-left, up-right, up-middle, left, right, behind, left-behind, right-behind, so on and so on. When something intense happens you nearly scare yourself half to death. I'm sure these would be really good for a scary movie. Very very impressed with this setup.<br /><br />OVERALL:<br />Overall, these are great headphones which provide high quality audio at a price you can live with. The only wish(s) I would have is possibly an equalizer and saving audio presets (much like the PX5). Also, maybe upping the max volume would be nice as well, cause I mean, it can never be too loud can it? In addition, higher bass is really needed, though I understand it is not that important for gaming..but at such a high price tag you really need to find every use for these things. I also worry about its durability, but since I have only had these for about a week I can not say anything about that yet..so far, so good.t of movies. I know that the majority of movies now are in Dolby digital surround sound, so these headphones would be perfect for it. I own a relatively new 1080i Vizio Razor which unforunately has about the worse speakers known to man. Anyway, I also have a laptop with a built in Blu-ray player and HDMI input. So typically, I just connect my laptop using HDMI into my TV and use my laptop as basically a Blu-ray player. This works very well actually, and the quality is amazing. Then I connected the digital cable from the receiver of the X41 directly to a digital port in my TV. I learned that this actually allows me to listen to movies in full Dolby surround sound and I can also listen to any TV channel (even when the TV is set to mute, since the audio is independent - which is awesome). So then I popped in a Blu-ray Harry Potter to my laptop and was off. All I can say is, WOW. I think these were made more for movies than for the Xbox. I could hear EVERYTHING from all different angles. Up-left, up-right, up-middle, left, right, behind, left-behind, right-behind, so on and so on. When something intense happens you nearly scare yourself half to death. I'm sure these would be really good for a scary movie. Very very impressed with this setup.     OVERALL:   Overall, these are great headphones which provide high quality audio at a price you can live with. The only wish(s) I would have is possibly an equalizer and saving audio presets (much like the PX5). Also, maybe upping the max volume would be nice as well, cause I mean, it can never be too loud can it? In addition, higher bass is really needed, though I understand it is not that important for gaming..but at such a high price tag you really need to find every use for these things. I also worry about its durability, but since I have only had these for about a week I can not say anything about that yet..so far, so good.

B004WPT3ZM|5.0|1986, What a year for metal. Arguably at it's peak at the time in the music industry, many of thrash's best bands were releasing their best/now classic albums. Everytime I listen to it, no matter what I can feel it, and that's just how powerful this record is. When Dave Remixed the Megadeth back catalog back in 2004, this album in particular lost that 'vibe' due to the remixing. Yes, technically speaking perhaps it is sonically better sounding for the instruments, but that's not what Megadeth is about. It's about making a statement, attitude, aggression, pissed, and everything that is pure in metal. This package brings back the fantastic original mixed album, remastered gloriously despite what anyone says, the tape hiss has been removed, leaving crystal clarity between songs. The acoustic stringed parts never sounded better, as with Junior's bass. Everything sounds like it should and it kills! The live show is great for the old-school fan, if your in it for quality performance, not just sound. And it sounds pretty nice for a 1987 bootleg recording! 0618918248|5.0|The God Delusion<br /><br />By Richard Dawkins<br /><br />Book Review<br /><br />By Richard E. Noble<br /><br />Richard Dawkins is British. He is a scientist and an avid supporter of Darwin and the concept of Natural Selection. He is a professor at Oxford University. He is also an atheist - or as close as one can get to an atheist by his own definition. He offers no support for \\"faith\\" or religion. The Bible and the God of the Old Testament are not two of his favorite things. In case there is any doubt about where Mr. Dawkins stands on those issues let me quote a snippet from page 31 of this text:<br /><br />\\"The God of the Old Testament is arguably the most unpleasant character in all fiction: jealous and proud of it; a petty, unjust, unforgiving control-freak; a vindictive, bloodthirsty, ethnic cleanser; a misogynistic, homophobic, racist, infanticidal, genocidal, filicidal, pestilential, megalomaniacal, sadomasochistic, capriciously, malevolent bully.\\"<br /><br />I should think that quote by itself should absolve the author from any returns made by purchasers claiming that they bought this book by mistake. They thought that the author was a Christian Theologist and now they would like their money back.<br /><br />He defines \\"faith\\" as belief beyond reason. And he further states that this is not a good thing. To encourage others to believe in what is not reasonable, or beyond logic and scientific reasoning, is the source of most of the world's problems and has been for centuries. He feels it should be discouraged.<br /><br />He is not a supporter of organized religions. He supports those who feel that teaching religion to children is a form of child abuse. He feels that educating children into religions should be stopped. Everyone notices the outrage of this practice when viewing the practice among religions not of their choice but find the whole process legitimate with their own children and their religious choice.<br />I would say that this book is basically an argument against belief in God or a God and the dangers of organized religion. The author deals with this controversial subject intellectually and reasonably. His views are very strong but he supports them with logical arguments and science.<br /><br />He dismisses the proofs for the existence of God by St. Thomas Aquinas in as quick and a simple a fashion as I have ever read. He covers many of the basic philosophical arguments in a simple and direct language. For a more in depth analysis of this subject I would recommend \\"The Impossibility of God\\" [[ASIN:1591021200 The Impossibility of God]] edited by Michael Martin and Rici Monnier.<br /><br />The author says that he is attempting to open people's awareness and especially their awareness of the ramifications of Darwin's principle of Natural Selection.<br />He has got my curiosity. I am interested in his explanations and I am certainly not as aware as he would like me to be.<br /><br />For example: At one point in the book he argues with those who contend that the Universe and Life could not have been a matter of chance. The author agrees but contends that the argument is not between chance and design by a supernatural creator but between chance and Natural Selection.<br /><br />I'm of the opinion that chance is fine. It is the only reasonable alternative and an acceptable answer. To posit God as an answer to the complicated origin of life and the Universe when there is no evidence of the existence of such a phenomenon is the same as saying Santa Clause did it or it was the Fairy Queen who is responsible for life and the Universe. It is a non-sequitur.<br /><br />I can understand the author's position in choosing Natural Selection as the origin of life but I do not see how Natural Selection answers the question of the origin of the Universe. Natural Selection is also subject to the infinite regression argument as is God.<br /><br />To say that the Universe always was and always will be in one shape or form or another is fine with me. I see no other rational alternative at this time. To say that it \\"came about\\" via a process of \\"Natural Selection,\\" I find confusing. Clearly I need to be made more aware. I have another of the author's books on my reading shelf \\"The Extended Phenotype.\\" [[ASIN:0198576099 The Extended Phenotype: The Gene as a Unit of Selection]]  I will read that and see if I can become more aware.<br /><br />This book, The God Delusion, is simple, easy to read and covers the basics of apostasy as I see it. The author pulls no punches and presents his view confidently and unabashed.<br /><br />I commend the author, Richard Dawkins, for speaking out as forcefully as he does. Theologists and the modern crowd of evangelicals are not the least bit timid in making their superstitions public. I see no reason why those of a contrary and more rational opinion should not do likewise.<br /><br />Richard Noble - The Hobo Philosopher - Author of:<br /><br />\\"Mein Kampf - Analysis of Book One - History.ind confusing. Clearly I need to be made more aware. I have another of the author's books on my reading shelf \\"The Extended Phenotype.\\" [[ASIN:0198576099 The Extended Phenotype: The Gene as a Unit of Selection]]  I will read that and see if I can become more aware.  This book, The God Delusion, is simple, easy to read and covers the basics of apostasy as I see it. The author pulls no punches and presents his view confidently and unabashed.   I commend the author, Richard Dawkins, for speaking out as forcefully as he does. Theologists and the modern crowd of evangelicals are not the least bit timid in making their superstitions public. I see no reason why those of a contrary and more rational opinion should not do likewise.   Richard Noble - The Hobo Philosopher - Author of:   \\"Mein Kampf - Analysis of Book One - History.

0007250916|5.0|Cancer is one of America's most feared illnesses. It attacks suddenly and indiscriminately, and many of the treatments for it are just as deadly as the affliction itself. Mukherjee covers both the social and medical history of this subject. Up until the latter half of the twentieth century, cancer survival was seen as a battle to be fought in private. During the 1950s, as the author informs us, the very word \\"cancer\\" was considered too indecent to appear in print. A cancer physician himself, Mukherjee examines the illness not so much from a clinical perspective, but from a \\"human\\" one. How long has it been around? More importantly, how can it be cured? These are only a few of the questions that the author tackles in language that is both informative and easy to understand.

B002NPCUVM|4.0|Reed and Irving deliver a clear, straightforward adaptation of Shelley's classic novel that older children will be able to both enjoy and understand. Soft, surreal, black and white illustrations set the stage for this gripping, elegant narrative. Facial expressions are never dull, and at times border on the melodramatic. The centerpiece of this work is the Monster himself - towering and lanky with long, disproportional limbs, this creature is dark and frightening, yet expressive and laden with undeniable human thoughts and emotions. Part of the Puffin Classic Graphics series, this graphic adaptation is one that can certainly stand apart from the original. Recommended for Ages 11-15.

037571457X|5.0|This graphic memoir documents the Iranian childhood of Marjane Satrapi, the only child of Marxist parents. Beginning with the Islamic revolution of 1979, the author uses black and white drawings in a simple comic-strip format to invoke Iran's tumultuous history, from prehistory days, to the eventual overthrow of the Shah and the triumph of the restrictive Islamic regime. At the heart of this memoir, however, is Marjane's beloved family. Her supportive parents, grandmother, and relatives are as endearing as the spirited, outspoken young girl who narrates their family's story. Persepolis came to the silver screen in 2007, and was named a New York Times Notable Book. Recommended for ages 16-Up for language and violence.

B0055D3EOG|3.0|This is the type of movie that makes me wonder if movie producers sit around a table and say \\"it should be scary, but not too scary, or it won't appeal to a wide audience...\\" I wonder what the result would be if someone actually tried to make a movie that was really terrifying. In my opinion, the scariest movies let you invent the bad guy in your own mind, based upon the little hints and things that the movie shows you. If you reveal the bad guy and he looks like a dude wearing a lot of makeup and a costume, it takes all of the suspense away. And it makes the audience members feel like a bunch of ninnies for being so unnerved to begin with. I liked what another reviewer said about the demon looking like Darth Mal from Star Wars. I agree- except Darth Mal was much scarier.    I am a big fan (and critic) of horror movies. This one was edgy and intriguing in the beginning, and I agree with a lot of others in that the whole thing took a downward turn around 3/4 of the way through. Its funny, you watch enough movies and you start to be able to pinpoint the exact moment when the script or the action loses you. I guess the acceptable level of ridiculousness is different for everyone, but this one presses the boundaries of even the most accepting audiences.    Overall, I liked it, despite my complaints. A girl can like something even though she thinks its silly, right? (there are so many jokes that could potentially be inserted here that I have opted out altogether). The ending didn't completely ruin the whole thing, but I walked away from it giggling instead of being slightly creeped out.

Conceived for the sole purpose of providing a bone marrow transplant for her sister Kate, who diagnosed with a rare form of leukemia at the age of 2, Anna has been providing her with tissue samples from birth. When Anna learns of the potential long-term effects of the kidney transplant she is expected to provide, she at last decides to claim her life, and her body, for her own. Picoult deals with a controversial topic with surprising grace and scope that covers not just Anna's story, but represents each member of the family. This slow-moving potboiler is not without some flaws. It suffers from the teeth-grating aggravation of unnecessary subplots and backstory (these can be skipped without the reader missing much), as well as a rather annoying surprise ending. B004UXUSIM|5.0|It has been nearly 25 years since I checked out a new Woody Allen film. I was a huge fan of his work in the late 60's and the 1970's but for the most part Woody kinda lost me after that. Several weeks ago a friend called me raving about \\"Midnight In Paris\\". He didn't tell me a whole lot about it but assured me that I would love it. I took the day off today and one of the things on my \\"to do\\" list was to check out this flick. I went to an 11:15 A.M. screening this morning and although there only about 10 people in the theater I wanted to stand up and cheer when they rolled the credits. For me \\"Midnight In Paris\\" was a sheer delight.  In fact, this is a film that I would definitely like to see again.<br /><br />\\"Midnight In Paris\\" stars Owen Wilson as aspiring novelist Gil Pender and Rachel McAdams as his lovely fiancee Inez.  The couple are visiting \\"The CIty of Light\\" with Inez's parents.  Gil and Inez seem very much in love as the film opens but cracks quickly begin to develop in the relationship.  Gil is a successful Hollywood screenwriter who has simply become bored with his work and dreams of living and working in Paris the way the great artists and writers of the 1920's did.  Inez has other ideas.  She longs for the glamorous life in Malibu with all of the amenities.  Inez is definitely going to be high maintenance.  Gil feels at one with this place and wants to explore the streets of the city and savor the essence of Paris.  Inez prefers to go off with friends and take in the art galleries and museums.  They are slowly drifting apart.  Gil's life would forever change one evening when at the stroke of midnight a limo pulls up alongside him and the occupants invite him to join them.  Suddenly and remarkably Gil finds himself  smack dab in the middle of the 1920's Paris he has always read and dreamed of.  Furthermore he has the opportunity to meet and greet several of the legendary figures who were living in Paris at that time.  That list would include writers Ernest Hemingway, F. Scott Fitzgerald, and T.S. Eliot, the legendary songwriter Cole Porter along with jazz great Josephine Baker and a group of artists including Pablo Picasso, Salvador Dali and Paul Gauguin.  Gil desperately wants to show Inez what he has been experiencing but only he is allowed to enter into this bizarre netherworld.  During his travels Gil also meets a ravishing young lady named Adriana (Marion Cotillard) with whom he has much in common.  Here finally is a place where he feels fulfilled.  Meanwhile, as you might expect all of these improbable events do not bode well for the future of Gil and Inez's relationship.<br /><br />I simply cannot overstate how much I enjoyed \\"Midnight In Paris\\".  The views of Paris both during the day and at night were nothing short of stunning.  The photography alone is worth the price of admission.  And in the finest tradition of Woody Allen films the music was also tremendous.There are a whole host of great selections from that era.  The acting was superb and the writing top drawer.  Woody Allen has outdone himself this time.  \\"Midnight In Paris\\" is one of those rare films that can be enjoyed by teens and seniors and everyone in between.  Very highly recommended!nest Hemingway, F. Scott Fitzgerald, and T.S. B0012Y1J3K|4.0|UPDATE: [I am adding this in response to a comment] If you are not familiar with Brahms it would probably be better to buy selected pieces of his compositions instead of this large box set. The quality of the set is high, but the performers are not regarded as the top of the line. However, the perception of a reviewer does not necessarily correspond with another potential listener. Therefore all reviews are opinions that may or may not be agreed upon when another listener hears the same pieces.  My own experience is that listening to classical music leads to very subjective views of performers and pieces that potentially can lead to very long arguments into the night.  This Brahms set is so cheap so you cannot go wrong in case you would like to experience Brahms. It will also serve as a reference point. I would not personally pick the Brahms canon from this set (e.g. Symphonies, Piano Concertos, Requiem) since there are many superior performances.  However, I have had much joy exploring the chamber music and the vocal music in the collection. I have come across pieces in this collection that I would not normally have acquired, and this is the beauty about these types of box sets. As you are drawn to certain pieces you can expand your collection of those by listening to other performances. My point is that a box set like this one is simply a reference point for exploring Brahms' music. At this price (a little more than a dollar per cd) you cannot go wrong, which of course is part of Brilliant Classics' strategy. So if you have heard some of the more famous Brahms pieces (e.g. the symphonies) and now are curious about Brahms and his music there is really no better starting point.<br /><br />Some physical aspects: The 60 cds come in a sturdy cardboard box that you open from the top. The contents (summary) of each cd is printed on the backside of the box. The cds are inserted into relatively sturdy cardboard sleeves which have the information of the music printed on the back of it (which is nice - EMI often fails to do this). The sleeves are numbered and color coded so it is easy to navigate. In addition, there is an extra cd that contains digital information (track lists, biography, liner notes, texts of the vocal works, and printable versions of the liner notes and texts of the vocals).<br /><br />__________________________<br />ORCHESTRAL MUSIC:<br />1: Symphony No. 1<br />Netherlands Philharmonic Orchestra, Jaap van Zweden<br />2: Symphony No. 2<br />Radio Filharmonisch Orkest Holland, Jaap van Zweden<br />3. B000RP4LEO|5.0|When I heard her performance in a Beethoven documentary, I immediately went and purchased the CD. Something about her interpretation of Beethoven sonatas is incredible. I'm a teenager with a varied taste in music, but this is some of the best classical music I've ever heard.
B001WCN23W|4.0|This is a review of the 2CD Deluxe version of Sticky Fingers, released in June 2015.<br /><br />I've only rated this re-release as four stars, although Sticky Fingers is one of the best albums of the Rolling Stones' extensive catalogue and certainly one of the classic albums of the 1970s. If you're collecting 1970s music, you need to have this CD.<br /><br />But the reason I'm giving this edition 4 stars instead of the five that Sticky Fingers deserves is that the full capacity of the 2 CDs has not been used.<br /><br />CD 1 is the material on the original vinyl LP release, clocking in at just over 46 minutes playing time. There are no bonus tracks or extra material on CD1. CD 2 is five tracks of studio out takes from the Sticky Fingers sessions and 5 Stones live tracks from 1971, clocking in at a total playing time of just over 54 minutes.<br /><br />Since a vinyl LP only held about 40 minutes of music - twenty minutes per side - and CDs were designed to hold 75 minutes of music, I think that the full playing time of both CDs in the Deluxe version should have been used by filling it up with bonus tracks. I have no doubt that the Rolling Stones archives contain a lot of top quality material from this period which could have been used. But it wasn't, so one star deducted.<br /><br />Having said that, Sticky Fingers is one of the essential 1970s albums and this 2 CD Deluxe set is still a worthwhile version, despite the full CD storage capacity not being used.

0061726826|5.0|Wow, \\"deadliest of all deadly things\\". I've read about love before, but haven't seen or heard it described like that! This is one dystopian story that focuses on the emotional connection among the characters as much as the society in which they live, which makes for a more personal and interesting story. The author does an incredible job of building a society where love in it's many forms is held up for examination...love between and by parents, siblings, friends and those of the same gender...    The storyline touches on a number of interesting ideas and perhaps the one of greatest impact, what a society is willing to give up in lieu of personal freedoms is seamlessly woven throughout to great effect. The use of characters who had never known another way of life was thought provoking when played against the lives of sympathizers and the \\"Invalids\\". As the story unfolds, the reader gets to explore the idea of how ceding human rights and humanity by allowing politicians and governments to determine what is or isn't safe is scary and [for THIS adult reader] too familiar for comfort --\\"a cautionary tale\\" indeed.    This book would be a great read-along/compare-contrast for middle school students studying the holocaust. The parallels of how a society goes about marginalizing a segment of its population (Invalids) and then determining that if they can't make them disappear from memory that deadly force against them is acceptable would lead to interesting class discussion.    Along with the bigger ideas presented in the story, other situations more familiar to the daily lives of teens are woven in as well, \\"I'd never understood how Hana could lie so often and so easily. But just like anything else, lying becomes easier the more you do it.\\" hmmmm....  I will be recommending this book to teens in my library who are exploring this type of fiction. The book's references to running will likely make it 'a sure thing' for girls who love running or cross-country as a sport.

0553801473|2.0|The first two books in the Martin series were utterly compelling; I couldn't put them down. I was immersed in the story lines, and the character development was truly outstanding. Unfortunately, as the series went on, Martin began going off on frustrating tangents that weakened the original stories. In the fourth book, rather than bringing satisfying conclusions and telling the original stories, he brought in a multitude of peripheral story lines and characters. Why not just begin another series altogether? Honestly, I found myself simply skimming along and bored with the fourth book, but had hopes that the fifth would bring closure. I hardly dare bring in such a canaille comparison, but it reminds me of the silly \\"Left Behind\\" series I read as an 8th grader, wherein there could be no explanation for the release of book after book without any real plot movement. The only possible reasons would be either financial gain or poor writing skills. I stopped reading those because I got bored. After the fifth book in Martin's series, I am about to stop bothering with his books, as well. I am bored. Bored and frustrated. This could have been another truly compelling book, but it's just silly. It just continues to string readers along, wishing for something worthwhile, wishing for some closure. I used to share the original books with enthusiasm, but my appreciation has waned. Very, very frustrating. What a disappointment.
B002MQYOFW|5.0|I didn't want to read this book. If you look at the majority of my past reviews you will notice I tend to stray from popular, bestseller novels as I often times find them overwritten, overhyped, and typically very boring works of fiction. Then there is the fact that \\"The Hunger Games\\" is usually referred to as a \\"Young Adult\\" novel where it will undoubtedly be grouped with books about lovestruck teenage vampires, lovestruck teenage werewolves, lovestruck teenage wizards, and lovestruck teenage students. \\"The Hunger Games\\" has so many things going against it, it's a surprise I even sat down and decided to read it at all.    But, the bigger surprise, is that I LOVED this book. Not since the 2 part epic disasterpiece \\"Flood/Ark\\" by Stephen Baxter have I been so enthralled and so wrapped up in characters, story and plot.     Where \\"The Hunger Games\\" succeeds is hard to pinpoint because it succeeds in so many places. First there's the incredible plot. Too many times in post-apocalyptical fiction we are presented with one of two ideas: a bleak barren future with no hope, or a technologically advanced society that rises from the ashes and begins anew. \\"The Hunger Games\\" melds both of those ideas into one uncannily believable plot that one wonders if the author, Suzanne Collins, can see into the coming future. Think about it: a destroyed United States of America, a communist run state, an eagerly anticipated and much hyped gladiator type fight to the death?     And that brings us to the plot, which, is outstanding as well. Like I say in most of my reviews, you can get a much more in-depth synopsis from someone else, but the idea of Katniss, plunged into a fight to the death match of wits, brawn and survival was so well written and flowed along so nicely that it was impossible to put this one down. Like most good books I read, I flew through this one in a matter of only 2 days.    Finally, major praise goes to Suzanne Collins. Much like J.K. Rowling of Harry Potter fame, Collins is an amazing author who obviously knows how to write a successful, addicting, and thoroughly enjoyable novel. Not since the just mentioned Harry Potter series have I read a series book that I enjoyed this much.     There is literally nothing, yes you read that right, NOTHING, that I can say in way of criticism here. Honestly, this is one of the most perfect novels I have read and I cannot wait until I get my hands on the 2nd one \\"Catching Fire\\".

B004WJRF6C|5.0|Of course, Paul had to start his remaster series with Band on the Run, being one of his biggest sellers, and of course he was busy with the Beatles remaster campaign (high time for that as well).  That said, what was the delay with McCartney being released, at long last?  For one thing, it was his first solo album, and it was one of his nicest ones.  This is a much better album than casual listeners and critics would give him credit for.  He was rediscovering himself as a musician, getting to know himself again.  There are no major political or social statements here, just Paul relaxing and learning to enjoy life again, and this is the start of the result.  Junk and Teddy Boy were two songs he'd auditioned for a Beatles album, but these were rebuffed, only to finally see the light of day on this album.  Oo You and Momma Miss America are two great guitar jams, which segue qite nicely into Singalong Junk, which sets the stage for what should have been a breakthrough smash single, Maybe I'm Amazed.  I was definitely amazed he managed to play all the instruments himself as it sounded like a full band album in 1970, the start of a period in which rock music in general was streamlined - no crazy, over-the-top, albeit much beloved, late 60s experimentation.  Listening to this album again after purchasing the remaster even warmed me up to Kreen-Akrore, which was not a huge favorite of mine.  My only problem was it was so quiet before, it was a bit irritating to listen to in such low fidelity, but its quality is brought out via digital remastering.  The guitar solo and wordless harmonies are a nice way to close this album, and I feel this should be given a good chance.  I am so looking forward to the remastering of the rest of his catalogue.

B000EBD9TY|5.0|Viewed: 2/05, 2/06, 7/11<br />Rate: 10<br /><br />2/06: Take a delicate, pretty flower. It's all about \\"Oh Dahling,\\" \\"Precious things,\\" and the likes. Enter an animal who tears it all up and smashes it all into pieces. That's what happened between Blanche DuBois and Stanley Kowalski. A Streetcar Named Desire is a fast, furious film that redefines the word acting. It is an important film in terms of acting, emotions, character work, and censorship issue. Marlon Brando, in this film, makes a name for himself as the most influential actor for the next generation of actors that would come and take what was so evident of Brando's style. Vivien Leigh tops herself in A Streetcar Named Desire, over what she had done in Gone with the Wind. Never again acting will be this good as compared to what Marlon Brando and Vivien Leigh have done in A Streetcar Named Desire. This is all about naked passion, raw emotions, and fire in clash with sensitivity, pretentiousness, and airiness. In the end, A Streetcar Named Desire is truly revered for setting standards of what a film is supposed to be all about. All in all, A Streetcar Named Desire contains an outstanding cast giving tremendous performances with a brilliant story that is marvelously directed by Elia Kazan.<br /><br />7/11: A Streetcar Named Desire is a landmark film because it is about a changing of guards between Old Hollywood and New Hollywood through Vivien Leigh and Marlon Brando. Obviously, the cast was intimidated by Marlon's presence, and Vivien stayed with him mightily throughout the film to the point of giving the third greatest acting performance in screen history. Finally, it's Marlon who steals the film and becomes an overnight superstar based on his raw animalism and indescribable method acting. It's unlike any kind of acting seen before the film, and he should be rightly credited for single-handedly changing acting as it was known before that time. A Streetcar Named Desire is an important film for this reason alone. Every time I see it, I see greatness, and I see nothing else but Brando and Vivien's titanic performances. All in all, Elia Kazan does something so remarkable in A Streetcar Named Desire that we all forget that it was supposed to be a theatrical play.ne. Every time I see it, I see greatness, and I see nothing else but Brando and Vivien's titanic performances. All in all, Elia Kazan does something so remarkable in A Streetcar Named Desire that we all forget that it was supposed to be a theatrical play.

B004WS7QN0|4.0|It is ironic that I write this review in the week that sees the demise of the British tabloid `News of the World' after which the Queen 1977 album was named. This strong and increasingly commercial Queen album came after 'Day at the races' and shows experimentation and a departure from the classic early Queen sound of their first five albums. So now it was bye bye progressive rock elements and hello to the embracing of popular rock, new influences and experimentation. This is Queen at their peak in the 70's trying to deal with the unveiling of the forces of punk and hard rock. (1977 saw both the arrival of `The Clash' and `Van Halen'). And this is how they responded...<br /><br />The album opens with possibly the world's most popular song chant of the last 30 years - from cheering sports fans of a hundred nationalities, teenagers, middle-class professionals, high society, to school children and grandparents - nearly everyone has at sometime participated in the community stomp and hand clap and joyful shout of `We will, we will rock you'. Most of these millions may not have heard of Brian May but this single has since played at every Queen concert followed closely by `We are the champions'. These two worldwide hit songs alone make this album a standout. The only reason this album is not Queen's quintessential great album is because the incredibly high standards of their previous albums like `Night at the Opera'.<br /><br />I like the 2011 `News of the World' case like all the 2011 remasters, but was surprised to see no additional photos with the CD lyrics. Perhaps these only come with the deluxe version? I also find the sound quality improvements not nearly as noticeable as what I did with the \\"Queen 2\\" 2011 remaster. (See my review '2011 Remaster compared to 1991 Queen 2, April 1, 2011').<br /><br />Again what is noticeable is that when comparing the two versions, I turn down the 2011 remaster as the volume has been lifted. Like with the `Day at the Races' remaster, each time I thought how great a track sounded on the 2011, I was surprised that when I raised the volume listening to 1991 remaster it sounded as good. Having said that, I do like the increased volume of the 2011 remaster, it is just not fair to compare the two versions at different volumes as you think you are hearing the detail of the bass and greater vocal definition whereas it is because it is louder.<br /><br />I will comment briefly on three tracks where I thought the 2011 remaster definitely showed improvement. One of my favourite Queen tracks of all time, `Spread your wings' shows a big improvement in the cleaning up of excess sound around the drums, bass and cymbals. The snare drum sound that previously bled into the overall sound especially during choruses and louder sections, is more defined and crisper and bass has more tone where it previously tended to boom. You hear more detail of the cymbals including when Roger hits on the bell of the cymbal and the wash does not seem to blur into the overall sound. So overall when listening to the song, you hear a clearer, more detailed and defined sound of all the instruments and voice.<br /><br />\\"Get down, make love\\" a track that first showed the darker, decadent side of Queen, sounds menacingly clear with amazing bass work from John Deacon that I've never noticed before. The drums crack with a force and the spaces between seem to emphasise the cutting cymbals.<br /><br />The hard rocking \\"It's late\\" sounds so much better. Because of the intensity of guitars, banks of vocal harmonies and sheer power, the intense sections previously sounded loud and possibly messy. There is now increased definition that allows you to hear a separation of the growl of the guitar and cymbals. I've always liked this track but enjoyed this so much more hearing the tones of Brian's guitar at the outset, plus more sense of the vocal richness rather than just loudness with all the other instruments in the final section.<br /><br />ForQueen fans - we buy in the hope that this is indeed a better sound quality. For listeners who already have the 1991 remaster - consider carefully whether it is worth the repurchase as the older 1991 remaster holds up as a good recording. And for those who only have Queen Greatest hits packages, buy this. You'll be pleasantly surprised with the variety of styles and the sheer brilliance of this quartet.better sound quality. For listeners who already have the 1991 remaster - consider carefully whether it is worth the repurchase as the older 1991 remaster holds up as a good recording. And for those who only have Queen Greatest hits packages, buy this. You'll be pleasantly surprised with the variety of styles and the sheer brilliance of this quartet.

But honestly, Yes fans, this disc sounds like well-recorded Starcastle, only with less imagination.  \\"Fly From Here\\"s finest feature is offering closure.

0802130208|3.0|I felt the same way after reading this novel as I did after watching the movie \\"Little Miss Sunshine.\\" Both are critically acclaimed, both won awards, and both were (are?) marketed as comedies...and both left me feeling like I was somehow tricked into spending my time on them. Also, both are really more like tragic character studies with a few funny scenes thrown in to keep you from falling into a depressive stupor as the characters' lives spiral downward.    I came to read this novel after hearing so much about how hilarious it is. For sure, the narrative, and in particular, I.J. Reilly's character hooked me into wanting to read more. But gut-busting-funny it was not. For one, the main character is an extremely odious and dis-likable person that just made me want to punch something every time he opened his mouth. Secondly, all the supporting characters are just as tragic and fairly dis-likable themselves (except maybe Jones or Angelo, who are merely pathetic). I guess you could consider it a mark of writing genius that such an attention-getting story was crafted from such horrible people, although I suppose its success may depend largely on readers who enjoy others' misfortunes?     In any case, there isn't much plot to speak of. This novel is more like a study of people's lives, and follows several characters around on their various misadventures, and how their lives all connect at some point. If you're looking for a fast-paced or action-driven story, this isn't it. The characters themselves are completely fascinating, and it's worth reading, if for no other reason than to get into the world of some truly bizarre and train-wreck-like people. I felt like the ending was abbreviated, but it's possible the author had intended to write more episodes in I.J. Reilly's life at some point.    Overall, I gave this book three stars mainly for false advertising. It's actually a pretty tragic novel, and I wasn't really prepared for a bit of melancholy right before bed. Also, Ireally disliked the characters, and it's hard to enjoy a book when you hate what you're reading. And while it was not particularly explicit, it was rather vulgar and suggestive at parts, and that can be a turn-off for anyone who leans toward more tasteful material. Worth reading once, if you have a strong stomach.

B004VSTP4Y|2.0|I loved Shiver, which is probably one of my favorite paranormal romances of all time.  Linger... was okay. Isabel, to me, was completely one-dimensional, and Cole was only slightly better.    Then... the plot holes.  <<<SPOILERS>>>    At the end of Linger, we learn that Sam's cure isn't real, that the wolf-virus is still inside of him, and will eventually build up and kill him, like it almost killed Grace.  This is *completely ignored* in Forever, in which Sam is cured!  Cole spends the entire book trying to find a cure and, at the end, we're left with the same cure that supposedly didn't work two books earlier.  Another problem... Isabel's big \\"sacrifice\\" (???) that she makes by running out into the middle of the wolf hunt could have just as easily been performed by Cole two minutes earlier, and there's no explanation of why this doesn't occur to him.  And there are no consequences to her for doing this, either.  She gets grounded.  Wah.    Finally, the whole thing with Officer Koenig suddenly showing up and giving his inheritence to Sam is just so much Deus ex Machina.  It doesn't make any sense for a whole host of reasons.  (This guy somehow figured out werewolves on his own?  He accepts this wholeheartedly with no proof?  And he's giving away his family inheritence... to be nice?)    All in all, I was very disappointed with this story, from the slow pacing to the plot holes to the lack of any real emotional connection between the characters.  Oh, and the end, in which we expect to finally find out what happens with Sam and Grace?  Totally unsatisfying.  I think Stiefvater ought to have just left the series with the first book-- there just wasn't enough \\"story\\" here to warrant a trilogy.  It would have been terrific as a standalone novel.

B004Y1USV2|4.0|Having been a Yes fan since 1975 (when my older brother turned me onto \\"The Yes Album\\", I have been a devout fan of the band, buying anything and everything ever released by the band. \\"\\"Fly From Here\\" to me is simply one more chapter in the Yes legacy. There have been many very thoughful, positive and a few negative reviews of the new Yes album, but that shows the passion of the fans, and I will not go into a song by song review of the album since there have been so many great reviews already posted concerning the content of the disc. Rather, I would like to share my thoughts on the band as a whole and the rather obvious wide range of Yes styles that have graced our LP's, Cassettes and CD's over the past 43 years of the bands existance. \\"Yes\\" and \\"Time and a Word\\" encompassed the band finding it's sound with little hints here and there of the music to come. \\"The Yes Album\\" was a departure from the first two discs as it introduced us to Steve Howe and the truly \\"progressive\\" side of the band, but the \\"Yes Album\\" as great as it is was a snapshot in history as Yes has never released another album quite like it. The \\"Fragile\\", \\"CTTE\\", \\"TFTO\\",\\"Relayer\\" & \\"Going for the One\\" usher in what most Yes fans view as the \\"true\\" Yes sound and compositional style, one of which has many reviewers both personal and professional often are referring to when the wish is for Yes to return to form. During the course of those five releases the band's style and progression from release to release did hold a commmon thread, but the content of the albums varied a great deal. \\"Sound Chaser\\" would not fit on \\"CTTE\\" anymore than \\"The Ritual\\" would fit on \\"Time in the Word\\", but the music of that phase of the band is what makes Yes music the groundbreaking progressive powerhouse they are.    After Going for the One the band has never reached the same level of Yes compositional style, from Tormato through the latest Fly From Here release, but we have been treated to some great music during this period, just not in the same groundbreaking sound and style of the 70's period. Beginning with Tormato in 1978 Yes has released 10 albums through 2011, clearly not equal in whole to the 70's catalog, but still Yes music nonetheless.    I am thankful for getting new Yes music in 2011 regardless of who is in the band, it continues on the Yes legacy and shows them moving forwad instead of resting on the past. Reading all the reviews on Amazon and elsewhere of the new album, especially in regards to Jon Anderson & Rick Wakeman not being part of the band any longer, brings to mind an interview of Rick Wakeman on the 1996 Story of Yes DVD in which Wakeman says (and I paraphrase) that Yes Music is more of a concept or feeling than the sum of the parts of members of the band, no matter who those members may be. Wakeman goes on the say there very well may be a \\"Yes\\" long after he is dead and gone due to Yes music being this \\"concept\\".    No matter what your personal feelings are about the current lineup of the band or the \\"Fly From Here\\" release, it is still \\"Yes Music\\", and that fact is un-mistakable, not only on the Fly From Here CD but ALL yes music realased over the past 43 years. and I for one would much rather have Yes in any form be releasing Yes music in 2011 than to here of the demise of the band.     Just for fun I wanted to list the Yes members (having recorded music) over their 43 year career, and just by looking at this list it should make perfect sense as to the various sounds and styles of the band:    Vocals-Jon Anderson, Trevor Horn, Trevor Rabin, Benoit David  Guitar-Peter Banks, Steve Howe, Trevor Rabin, Billy Sherwood (The Ladder)  Keyboards-Tony Kaye, Rick Wakeman, Patrick Moraz, Billy Sherwood, Igor Khoroshev, Geoff Downes, Oliver Wakeman  Drums-Bill Bruford, Alan White.  Bass-Chris Squire    After all these years, it's still Yes Music to me.
B003NWS5AO|5.0|What can a reviewer add after slightly over 100 reviewers have weighed in?  Well, the only thing is that particularly person's take on said matter.  With that in mind, here goes...This is Robert Plant's absolute finest post-zep album.<br /><br />Maturity is a strange thing, it can sink a artist's muse to the point where whatever that artist does is a shadow of former glories.  When the bar has been set as high as what Robert Plant has accomplished as a member of Led Zeppelin that would seem to be more likely than not.  In a way it is true since no matter what fine music he put out it would be hard to say one of his solo albums could stand with Led Zeppelin I thru IV.  Then there is all the other albums the group put out which certainly had many more highpoints.  Realizing this it is with complete seriousness that I say none of Plant's solo outings matched quite the total heights of that vaulted catalog.  Sure, there is plenty of wheat to be harvested in any of his post-Zep work, yet not one entire album was a complete tour-de-force.  That, IMHO, has now changed.<br /><br />Band of Joy is the mature Robert Plant rising up with all of his influences to create a synergistic whole that can stand with anything he has ever done.  It stands with my favorite single Led Zeppelin albums those being the aforementioned I thru IV.  Like with Zeppelin it took a special group of musicians to create a sum greater than the parts.  Band of Joy is unequivocally that whole that propels Plant's vision and talents to rarified air.  Not only is every song on the album momentous, but if you've seen them live they absolutely can take, it would seem, any other artists stellar songs and propel them further.  Plus, in concert they always take a couple of Zep songs and re-imagine them in a completely new form that almost births a new experience.<br /><br />Buy this album if you thought \\"Raising Sang\\" was his reemergence as a musical force because this album has more earthy grit that electrifies his artistic gifts more.  One can only hope that this band has more to give in the future.  Even if they don't (I thought Emmylou's Spyboy would last) we have  this spectacular musical journey in which we all can truly be absorbed into.  I'd give it 6 stars if I could because this has made me into a Robert Plant fan at the tender age of 51!  I want to say that it isn't only due to Plant, he was blessed to get the perfect foils in Band of Joy.  A true musical treasure that is also a huge sonic treat as it is recorded quite well.  I've never heard such bending of low-e strings ( in my life) complimented with mandolin, steel guitar, acoustic guitar, and banjo.<br /><br />I'll shut up, I'm sure you get my message:  buy this album and be taken to a place no other music today can take you..  One can only hope that this band has more to give in the future.  Even if they don't (I thought Emmylou's Spyboy would last) we have  this spectacular musical journey in which we all can truly be absorbed into. I'll shut up, I'm sure you get my message:  buy this album and be taken to a place no other music today can take you.
0805211063|5.0|As Walter Benjamin indicates, Kafka's ouvre is the testament of our time. What we really needed was an attorney to litigate the absurd madness the direction of our civilization has taken. Kafka gave us that.<br />Now, let's set the record straight. There are a number of reviews here that partake in this madness. To understand Kafka, one must have shed real tears, and not only for oneself. Afficianados of Ayn Rand take note. The Castle is a masterpiece, perhaps even greater than The Trial (imo - yes), and one of the magisterial achievements in prose fiction. The terminal unfinished conversation, breaking off mid-sentence is ... perfection. The seal of the unanimous approval of destiny. What more needed to be said? The endless rondo of futility must continue unto death. A losing battle, initiated by an obscure mistake ... but we must fight on through the slough of materiality, pettiness, and despair until the end. What more appropriate condemnation?<br />Further, Harmon's translation is vastly superior to that of the Muirs. Be aware of this fact. Harmon's translations are the BEST. In time, I doubt whether the Muir translations will be read by any but scholars, the uneducated, or the unfortunate.

0553801473|2.0|Let's start with the BIG problem--the book doesn't really pick up until around page 562...which is the end of a chapter. And by \\"pick up\\" I mean \\"the endless repetition stops, and events actually start HAPPENING.\\"<br /><br />It's as if there are two books which have been jammed between two covers. There's the first book, in which GRRM proves that he can write a travelogue just as tedious as the notorious camping trip from Hell in Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows. Everyone is walking or sailing somewhere, the weather is bad, no one has any money or any men, and there are no end of scenes mentioning every food and beverage available. Oh, and pissing. Can't forget the pissing. GRRM never does.<br /><br />The first half of ADwD also includes a lot of scenes which appeared in the previous book from another character's point of view. This can be used to great effect if the two characters in the scene are seeing what's happening in two completely different lights. However, in this case, there is little difference. GRRM has effectively just C & P'd \\"Alaric said\\" in place of \\"Bob said.\\"<br /><br />And speaking of Bob--Dragons is crammed with \\"As you know, Bob\\" dialogue and narrative. Davos' and Daenerys' chapters are particularly bad; oftentimes I felt as if I was at a review site, reading a recap of the four previous books. The last chapter summarizes Dany's entire history, even though it's been mentioned at least seven or eight times prior to this. Tyrion's story, too, gets recapped. Oh, and we're reminded a few billion times that Tyrion killed his father. Just in case we forgot or anything.<br /><br />Catchphrases, too, are over-fondled. These show up frequently:<br /><br />\\"Where do whores go?\\" (Tyrion's chapters.)<br /><br />\\"Reek, Reek, it rhymes with [rhyming word].\\" (Reek's chapters.)<br /><br />\\"The night is dark and full of terrors.\\" (Jon's chapters and Melisandre's chapter.)  The ritual of R'hollr's nightfires, copied and pasted in its entirety ad nauseam, sounds dramatic at first, but it gets repeated so often that it starts to sound silly. Barring lands with midnight suns, most nights aren't known for being light.<br /><br />And then there's the second book, which starts two-thirds of the way in and in which all the questions that people have been asking for years start getting answered very fast. Some fairly key scenes get skipped over, too.<br /><br />Also, practically every \\"answer\\" scene ends on a cliffhanger, or what's intended to be a cliffhanger. They could not scream, \\"You'll have to buy the next book to find out what happens!\\" any louder.<br /><br />I've been going through everything with a mental red pen. At least 90% of the first 500 pages could have been cut down to a manageable size--from several chapters to one chapter, from one chapter to a paragraph or two.<br /><br />There are also a fair number of inconsistencies. Before, the silent sisters were described as the equivalent of contemplative nuns who take a vow of eternal silence. In this book, we're overtly told that a father saying to an eleven-year-old girl, \\"I'll give you to the silent sisters and then you'll never speak again\\" means that he was telling his daughter that she'd have her tongue cut out. Greyscale was one word before--now it's \\"grey scale.\\" Before it was an illness that killed some children in the cradle and disfigured others, like Stannis Baratheon's daughter, Shireen. Now it's the Westeros-and-Free-Cities equivalent of leprosy, a disease which slowly transforms people into stone--such an illness does exist in the real world, but I think that Martin was just trying to come up with something that fit Shireen's scars. In fact, greyscale, or grey scale, is now so feared that one sufferer dares not reveal his illness lest his friends turn against him and even those who have the scars are shunned. It was stated before that Tywin Lannister's father, Tytos, so extravagantly wasted the Lannister fortune on a string of whores as to leave Tywinwith a hatred for prostitutes and a horror of being laughed at; now Tytos had one mistress that he treated like a wife. And so on. Martin may be trying for unreliable narration, but frankly, it doesn't come off that way.<br /><br />Now, do I have anything good to say about this book? Yes. I do like the answers to questions, cliffhangers or no; some are extremely satisfying. Martin's depiction of mutilation, torture and the resultant Stockholm syndrome was exceedingly well done. It was horrifying and unpleasant to read, but it was portrayed with painful, all-too-believable clarity. Jon Snow, my all-time least favorite character, improves dramatically.  I enjoyed most of the chapters with female characters, especially Arya's. Once Martin finally gets going, he tells the story pretty well.<br /><br />But this isn't enough to outweigh the problems. Not nearly enough.<br /><br />If I could, I would give it 1.5 stars. It doesn't really merit two.
0060936223|5.0|This is both an autobiography and biography in one. It is a riveting accounting of the years before Mapplethorpe and Patti became stars. It is a story about beauty and art and the creative process as it existed for this incredibly talented duo. While I thought an artist was defined as someone who could create things the rest of us couldn't, Patti and Robert believed the defining characteristic of an artist was that he or she could see things others didn't. Their ability to perceive the world in a different and unique way was what made them ultimately successful, admired (or reviled) artists as much as it was their ability to translate those visions into works of art. I couldn't put this book down and having finished it, I can't stop thinking about it.

B004Y1USJE|3.0|I've always loved Yes. Grew up in the 70s idolizing the band, especially Steve Howe, and even enjoyed the later Drama phase, minus Anderson, in its own way. In fact, I've bought every Yes album released and still enjoy many of them from time to time. The period from 'The Yes Album' to 'Going for the One' remains my favorite, but I've found something to like on every album since. Listening to a new Yes album, especially back in their prime, was often both exhilarating and challenging, with repeated listens necessary for the beautifully complex musical forms to fully bloom and engage. That was the hidden joy of progressive music and half the fun. What a rush.<br /><br />But times change. If I'd never heard of the current band, I'd say that the music's certainly more interesting and accomplished than most contemporary rock hitting the waves. And there's some solid musicianship here, too, especially Steve's acoustic work.<br /><br />Unfortunately, when compared to some of the other progressive (symphonic) rock coming out these days, especially from northern Europe, this release sounds surprisingly simplistic and tame to me. A few listens and time to move on. In contrast, the Flower Kings' most recent ('Sum of No Evil') is just one example of current prog-rock that both maintains and expands the genre in fresh, inspiring, even challenging ways. For me, sadly, 'Fly From Here' doesn't even come close.<br /><br />I wish the guys well, though, and expect that they'll find an audience to connect with their current offering. After all, with 40-odd years of Yes in all its varieties, Yes fans differ greatly. 'Fly From Here' is a recording that seems sure to highlight those differences. The good news for classic-prog fans like me is that other contemporary groups, like the Kings, are stepping up to fill the void. Head over to the 'progarchives' site and such to check out some great options that, IMO, far exceed 'FFH's' ability to tug at the beautiful memories of Yes' golden progressive era.<br /><br />But we're all Yes fans here, aren't we? I guess in the end it's just a matter of discovering what Yes means to each of us and choosing Yes music accordingly. Not a bad legacy at all for a band that has given so many of us such great joy through the years.
B000002H97|4.0|That Metallica are one of the greatest heavy metal bands in musical history cannot be disputed. Both commercially and musically, let alone the combination of these factors, it is diffcult to find another band with similarly heavy sound which has ever been as successfull as Metallica. Too bad that they ceased to exist in the early 1990s.    During the 1980s Metallica produced one very promising debut which would have been completely forgotten today had it not been followed by three supreme masterpieces. Then came the Black Album and the beginning of a profound change which was to become more and more repulsive with the passing years. The results were very decent and listenable albums such as ''Load'' and ''Reload'', which are no Metallica however, unsuccessful experiments such as ''S & M'', and some pure junk such as ''St Anger'' - which is hardly music, let alone Metallica. Significantly, the band's best album during the post-1991 period was a collection of covers and old gems (''Garage Inc.'').    Now the problem with the Black Album is not that it is conspicuously light and commercially mind-blowing. I am pretty sure that Metallica never sold themselves out, in other words they never compromised their artistic integrity for bigger sales. They never needed it: even in the 1980s they were one of the hottest tickets and one the bigest sellers in the genre. I am sure that the tendency that started with the Black Album, and later degenerated much further, was a natural and sincere one. And in the very beginning it did produce an album almost as fine as the classics from the 1980s.    Some of the lightest songs in the album - I understand the special term is ''mainstream'' - also happen to be some of the best ones, and they do demonstrate, not so much musical growth, but certainly a greatly expanded musical versatility. The great popularity of ''Nothing Else Matters'' and ''The Unforgiven'' is also their curse: it often prevents us from fully appreciating them. In the company of masterpieces, without hesitation I would put ''Enter Sandman'', ''Sad but True'' and ''Wherever I May Roam'' as well. Both the music and the lyrics are top-notch.     The problem with the Black Album is that it is very uneven, much more so than any of the previous ones (including ''Ride the Lightening'' which is by far the most uneven of these). Half of it is terrific, quite on par with, if different than, anything Metallica had produced before (see the previous paragraph). But the other half is consistently weaker. Even though there is not a single ''bad'' song here, few of them (''Holier than Thou'', ''Through the Never'', ''My Friend of Misery'') might have remained unreleased without any loss for world of music. The rest of the album, though containing fine pieces like ''Don't Tread on Me'', ''The Struggle Within'' and ''Of Wolf and Man'', is not quite on par with the five aforementined songs. To me they have always sounded somewhat laboured, monotonous and uninspired.    So what is the bottom line? Well, there is absolutely nothing epic about the Black Album, nothing like 'One' or 'Master of Puppets'' are you likely to encounter here. But this is a very poor reason for degrading the album. It may be distinctly light and it may be more simplified that the epic opuses from the 1980s - indeed it is both - but it also shows that Metallica can be as creative and profound on this more commercial and lightweight plane as they always have been on the more (or less?) rarefied one which they occupied during the 1980s.     One star down not for any other reason, but simply because the album can easily be split into two halves, one of them distinctly inferior to the other. Yet could anybody in 1991 have predicted what would happen in the next years?    P.S. Is it a coincidence that the Black Album, unlike the previous three ones, does not contain an instrumental? Hardly.
