B004DMIIO6|3.0|Judge David Johnson, DVD Verdict -- \\"For straight-up sensory overload, not much is going to eclipse the craziness of Goemon. Before I continue, fair warning: If CGI leaves you cold, steer clear. Like 300, Goemon is virtually all computer-generated, featuring actors with their prop swords (in most cases) standing in front of green screens delivering their lines. In fact, there were more than a few occasions that it felt like I was simply watching an extended cut-scene for a Japanese role-playing game on the PS3. I am on record as someone who has become ambivalent towards CGI overuse, especially with regards to action scenes, but I'll give Goemon a pass; from the outset we're in a hyper-stylized world and realism isn't a commodity. My two biggest problems stem from the substance and the style: 1) the film is not a brisk two hours, its myriad sub-plots, character arcs and exposition chunks slowing the momentum down far too much and, 2) the potentially coolest action moments were nearly impossible to see. I could handle a sagging pace--and the middle act of Goedon is glacial--if the action pay-off was ample, but mostly I was squinting just to decipher the over-the-top computer renderings. For example, there's a huge scene toward the end as Goemon scales a tower to square off with the evil lord and he has bound through ascending levels, defeating ninjas and dodging cannon fire. Nifty in theory but almost impossible to follow thanks to the overwhelming busy-ness and hyperactive edits that were stuffed in. Not that the Blu-ray wasn't trying, because the 2.35:1 transfer (1080p, MPEG-4 AVC) is a strong performer. The resolution provides an eyeful, which can be bittersweet: there is some seriously gorgeous effects to gawk at, but the enhanced clarity also pull the rug out from underneath some laughable visual effects. Two engrossing Dolby TrueHD audio tracks: Japanese 6.1 and English 6.1 (go with the original for the extra channel and the lack of dubbing) are included. The disc is rounded out by an hour's worth of behind-the-scenes content, showcasing how the film was staged and the effects were incorporated.\\"sc is rounded out by an hour's worth of behind-the-scenes content, showcasing how the film was staged and the effects were incorporated.\\"

0553801473|2.0|I only stumbled onto this series because of the HBO series.  And I devoured the first four books in about a week and a half, at the same time re-reading the Black Company series from the beginning even as I was in the middle of She is the Darkness. To say I like this particular genre would be an understatement.<br /><br />I fell in love with the series.  And that's been rare and rarer occurrence in recent years.  Truth be told, in fantasy genre, there are a lot of trash out there.  But when you love the genre, you wade through them in hopes of finding something like this series.  Even with the good books, after so many of them in so many years, they don't touch you as the early ones once did.  But this one certainly did.  I cannot even remember being as horrified and actually ANGRY at the villains as I was when I was reading through the Red Wedding.  When you're as jaded as I conceit myself to be, that's a treat indeed.<br /><br />So this book was a huge disappointment.  In fact, this seems another Wheel of Time in the making.  At the risk of sounding snobbish, that's not a compliment.  Maybe the author doesn't mind.  Churning books is lucrative, and as people invest in characters, they forgive much and dutifully buy the next installment.  but if you can't tell a story in about three books (the LotR standard), maybe you shouldn't write. (I know, the Black Company is like 7 books long but the change of POV narrator keeps the books pretty fresh)<br /><br />This book goes nowhere in particular, stews like the thin broth the starving masses (and there are many in this book) huddle around, and dissolves into a cliffhanger that actually gives no suspense.<br /><br />Bear with me for a sec.  Parents who prep the young ones for daycare in the morning may be familiar with an educational PBS program called Between the Lions.  One of the skits is a crudely animated short called \\"Cliffhanger\\" where a mountaineer perpetually hangs from a stunted tree limp on a cliff.  Each episode, he contrives a way to be rescued and in the end, he still ends up hanging from the cliff.  The music concludes, \\"Cliiiif hanger, hanging from the cliff.  That's why he's named... Cliff Hanger!\\"<br /><br />That's this book.<br /><br />However, I will grant the maps in the beginning of the book are drawn much nicer.<br /><br />I'll finish this series, no doubt.  And it can be redeemed with the resolution in the next book.  But I finish all my series, even the foul, unreadable ones. (see my Ed Greenwood book review)

0553801473|4.0|I'm surprised at some of the negative reviews. It's not great but it borders on being very good. There are lots of mini cliffhangers throughout the book - but an observant reader will be able to figure out which ones are faux and which are actually important.<br /><br />Things I thought were great - at last there is some Bran. The early scenes with Tyrion were very well written. The new characters he runs into were decently done. Most of the chapters were set in the North (always my favorite part of Westeros)and were so good I couldn't put it down. Martin really goes into the many rammifications of the Red Wedding - even into secondary characters like the Boltons and the Manderleys - in ways that I didn't expect and that I enjoyed reading.<br /><br />Theres a couple of Martell chapters, also some others. set in Kings Landing - all pretty good. Plus Asha and Melisandre have some good POV chapters.<br /><br />Things I didn't like so much - the scenes with Daenerys (but then she was never one of my favorite characters - so to me - no loss), some of the cliffhangers were completely unneccessary and run the risk of Martin jumping the shark by overusing this technique - in trying to replicate what he achieved earlier with Lord Eddard's death and the Red Wedding. If you are a reader for whom this would jump out at you - I could see some disappointment. Plus there could have been more Bran, Meera and Jojen.<br /><br />Overall - it's really good. New and well written fantasy is hard to find. I'm glad George Martin continued this story and I'm interested in how he will further it in the next volume. Very good job.

1594744769|5.0|Do you remember when you were a child and you came upon one of those books that just seemed magical to you? Something about them drew you in and wouldn't quite let you go, even after the last page was read. Being well over 30 I don't often stumble upon such reads, but I remember the magic, and when I picked up Ransom Rigg's book, intrigued by the title and the photos, I once again got to experience that magic that only a good book can bring. The story is beautifully told in the voice of teenager Jacob, who has grown up being told tales by his grandfather Abe, tales that he used to believe, about a home of peculiar children with special abilities - like being superstrong, invisible and able to fly. Being now a teenager, Jacob has come to accept his grandfather's stories as tall tales, but then something happens that changes everything and forces Jacob to once again reassess the truth. Mixed in with this story are the photos (genuine vintage photos the author has found and borrowed) depicting one peculiar thing after another, and this really adds to the story's magic, making you feel like you are looking through someone's old photoalbum. The whole edition is beautifully made with 3 coloured inlay and a lovely setting, it certainly is a collector's item if you are in to beautiful books. The only negative is that I want more NOW - the book does not answer everything and there is hopefully a sequel in the making. I, for one, can't wait to immerse myself in Mr Rigg's magical world again!

0007250916|4.0|Dr. Mukherjee's book might be described as a history of people either getting cancer or trying to do something about it.  Most of the book focuses on events since the late 1800s.  Because cancers usually occurs in later life, in earlier times many people had already died before they reached the age at which they might contract cancer.   Thus, there are few references to cancer in ancient medical works and few obvious instances of cancers in human remains from those times.  From about the European middle ages there are more references to cancer; but the only obvious way to deal with some cancers, by surgery, would often be worse than the disease because of the use of unsterilized tools and rarity of anesthesia for the patients.    Beginning in the late 1800s surgery became a practical option as asceptic techniques and anesthesia was available. This allowed for the beginning of decades of slow progress in treating cancer, marred by frequent misunderstandings of the nature of the disease and by the obsessional and excessive application of whatever techniques were at hand.  The obsessional and excessive response to cancer became quickly evident when William Halsted, an American surgeon, came up with the radical mastectomy in order to deal with breast cancer.  This surgery, which removed much other tissue, such as lymph nodes, besides the breast, was either overkill for those breast cancers which could be dealt with by surgery, or alternatively was insufficient for cancers which had already metasticized.  Halsted's belief that cancer would spread in a step by step progression from the breast to the near lymph nodes, and then on to the next lymph nodes, was incorrect; cancer can spread from the breast to a distant location.  Unfortunately, the clearest evidence that he was mistaken had wait about a century, until 1980, when the results of a randomized trial were released.    Sidney Farber in Boston could be considered the originator of chemotherapy for cancer.  He focusedon leukemia because it was the one cancer at the time (just after the Second World War) whose spread or remission could be measured quantitatively.  His discovery of chemotherapy agents followed an empirical approach with little underlying explanation of the nature of cancer.  Working with the philanthropist Mary Lasker, he obtained first large private funding for cancer research, and then a great increase in public funding in the Nixon administration.  By then Farber's approach, focused on empirical screening of chemicals for anti-cancer activity, had already been institutionalized at the National Cancer Institute in the form of a large program systematically screening chemicals for their effectiveness as chemotherapeutic agents. These agents tended to be chemicals that stopped cell division, as rapid cell division is a hallmark of cancers.  However, many normal tissues also have cells dividing regularly, so traditional chemotherapeutic agents are hard on the patient too; the hope is that you kill the cancer before the patient gives out. Just as the nature of cancer drove Halsted to come up with radical mastectomy, so too would traditional chemotherapies eventually be applied by frustrated clincians in extreme and unhelpful therapies in the late 1980s and early 1990s.    Only slowly did knowledge of the basic biology of cancer improve.  Some environmental causes of cancer, such as exposure to excessive radiation, had been known.  In the 1950s the ability of tobacco smoke to cause cancer was first strongly indicated, but without an understanding of the biology.  For some decades after World War Two the idea that viruses caused many human cancers took hold.  The result was another screening program at the National Cancer Institute, this time to find viruses that caused human cancers. Ultimately, the idea that viruses directly cause cancers has been found to be greatly overblown, thanks to our increased understanding of genetics and DNA.  Cancers require genetic changes that allow for unbridled cell division.  As viruses require a cell and its associated genetic machinery to reproduce, they sometimes accidentally incorporate a human cancer gene in their own virus genome and spread it.  Other viruses can cause cancers by modifying the genes involved in cell division.  But viruses don't seem to cause most human cancers.    Although all cancers involve cell division, cancers are not all alike.  Cancer cells sometimes retain the characteristics of the tissues from which they orginate.  For example, some breast cancers require estrogen to grow; since the 1960s, these cancers have been treatable with tamoxifen, a chemical which blocks estrogen from the cancer cells.      Our greatly improved knowledge of DNA is leading to more targeted cancer therapies with fewer side effects.  Now that some of the specific genes involved in cancers are known, cancers can sometimes be stopped using chemicals that stop these particular genes from working.  Since the late 1990s, therapies of this sort have become available.  They will probably never be a complete fix, as cancer cells evolve in response to chemical therapies just as bacteria evolve resistance to particular antibiotics. Still, the new therapies, and the use of screening techniques such as Pap smears that can sometimes detect a cancer before it develops much, suggest that improved outcomes for cancer treatment are likely.  Given the history of the field, we should not expect dramatic improvements or a complete cure, but things seem to be looking up nonetheless.

0062060554|5.0|Before I Go to Sleep is a thriller you won't be able to put down.  Even as you think you have it all figured out, there is a twist that forces you to reconsider what you know.  I was constantly thinking I knew how it was going to end, but each time new information would negate my theories.  It is not the kind of thriller you can't read at night ala Stephen King's novels, but it compels you to keep reading.  You just want to know the secret of Christine's past, hidden by her by amnesia.  In addition to it being a thrill ride, the plot of the novel itself...an amnesiac whose memories are erased each time she goes to sleep...gets you thinking about the meaning of friendship, family, and love.  Highly recommended, quick, easy read that will not disappoint.  Just be sure you have time to read it, because once you start, you won't want to stop!

0807014273|5.0|Viktor Frankl was, as he put it, \\"a professor in two fields, but a survivor of four camps - concentration camps, that is\\". Already a renowned psychotherapist, Frankl's experiences at Auschwitz and other concentration camps provided him profound and striking insights into human psychology. He sets them out in this brief and elegant book.<br /><br />Firstly, when put in a situation of extreme adversity or deprivation human personalities do not blur into one \\"uniform expression of the unstilled urge\\", as Sigmund Freud had supposed they would but, on the contrary, true personalities are accentuated. Secondly, despair and depression are not at all correlated with the experience of adversity, but if anything inversely so: in our modern, plentiful and comfortable times, neuroses are legion. By contrast, on the whole they weren't in Nazi death camps. Frankl was uniquely placed and qualified to comment on this; Freud was not: \\"Thank heaven,\\" Frankl remarks dryly, \\"Freud was spared knowing the concentration camps from the inside\\".<br /><br />This seems right: I dare say you don't see much neuroticism in modern day Somalia either (though I do quite like the idea of obsessive-compulsive Mogadishan parents pushing their kids into extra cello lessons.)<br /><br />Frankl uses his anecdotal observations to propose what was in its day a revolutionary psychology: it isn't our primal physical urges which determine our behaviour, with intellectual constructions being mere epiphenomenal by-products (Freud would have it that love, for example, was a spin-off of the deeper primal sexual urge), but the other way round: it is the intellectual content - the *meaning* of our lives that shapes and drives our behaviour and, crucially, our happiness.<br /><br />The more profound and compelling you find the meaning in your own life, the less neurotic you're likely to be.<br /><br />This leaves open the question of what \\"meaning\\" might be, and what might make a profound and compelling one. This question Frankl doesn't answer, rightly I think, other in rather an airy fashion. Anecdotally, meanings are more likely to count as profound and compelling the more gravely connected with the \\"tragic triad\\" of pain, guilt and death they are (no shortage, therefore, at Auschwitz). But beyond those axes, the implication will be that we, the users, determine our own meaning.<br /><br />This may perhaps be a little self-fulfilling, and neurosis may be a product of existential frustration (in other words the confounding of one's own quest for meaning through preoccupation with things you don't truly value): Frankl cites a senior American diplomat who sought treatment from depression arising from discontent with his working life. Frankl's advice was not undergo psychotherapy, but to change his job to something he cared more about!<br /><br />But all the same this seems to me a plausible explanation for modern melancholy: who, these days, isn't continually and forcibly preoccupied with things he or she doesn't truly value? That seems to perfectly capture the \\"asset rich, time poor\\" existence.<br /><br />This is a short book, but it's a gem: the message of plurality and self-determination are ones which should strike harmonious chords in the ears of those, like this reviewer, who are nudging into middle age and wondering if it is quite all what it cracked up to be.<br /><br />Olly Buxtonly I think, other in rather an airy fashion. Anecdotally, meanings are more likely to count as profound and compelling the more gravely connected with the \\"tragic triad\\" of pain, guilt and death they are (no shortage, therefore, at Auschwitz). But beyond those axes, the implication will be that we, the users, determine our own meaning.     This may perhaps be a little self-fulfilling, and neurosis may be a product of existential frustration (in other words the confounding of one's own quest for meaning through preoccupation with things you don't truly value): Frankl cites a senior American diplomat who sought treatment from depression arising from discontent with his working life. Frankl's advice was not undergo psychotherapy, but to change his job to something he cared more about!     But all the same this seems to me a plausible explanation for modern melancholy: who, these days, isn't continually and forcibly preoccupied with things he or she doesn't truly value? That seems to perfectly capture the \\"asset rich, time poor\\" existence.     This is a short book, but it's a gem: the message of plurality and self-determination are ones which should strike harmonious chords in the ears of those, like this reviewer, who are nudging into middle age and wondering if it is quite all what it cracked up to be.     Olly Buxton
0553801473|3.0|In the long, long years between ASoS and AFFC, GRRM wrote that he was having trouble figuring out how to solve what he termed the \\"Meereenese knot,\\" AKA the Daenerys storyline. A mess of characters were supposed to be converging on Daenerys in Meereen, but timing issues in the story were making it impossible for him to figure out how to pace the storyline to make it all work. His solution to the Meereenese knot? Do nothing about it at all. Only one character who was supposed to arrive in Meereen and meet Daenerys does so by the end of ADwD. Furthermore, after hundreds of pages devoted to the city, Meereen is no better off at the end of ADwD than it was at the beginning. Absolutely nothing happens that could not have been resolved in 100 pages or less. Daenerys only had a few chapters per book in the first three books, but she managed to achieve more character development in those books than she does in nearly a dozen chapters in this one. What was the point of the Hizdahr marriage? Do we need so many pages devoted to her holding court or debating whether or not to open the fighting pits?<br /><br />GRRM is starting to veer dangerously into George Lucas territory here. He must needs find a better editor, and soon. Someone who is comfortable telling him when his language has moved from \\"verbose but fascinating\\" into \\"ridiculously long-winded and meandering.\\" Do we need to hear a detailed description of every single bite of food every single character happens to eat or see? I know GRRM is a rotund man, but it's getting to be silly. And how many times can one author write about how the juices (or the grease) run down a character's chin (or their beard, or their entire face, or their leg?) Seriously...we get it. People in Westeros eat with the fervor and fine motor skills of a two year old encountering ice cream for the first time.<br /><br />It's mind-boggling to think about how much story was packed into the first three books compared to how little is packed into the last two. Almost no one's plot has advanced even the smallest amount since ASoS. Only Jon's story has seen significant movement, and...well...<br /><br />Where this book goes right (Lord Manderly baking the Freys into pies and then eating them! \\"The North remembers.\\" Arya's first official assassination! Sympathy for Theon! The fall of Cersei! '\\"Ghost,\\" he whispered.'), it goes very right. Where it's wrong, it's simply boring and superfluous. It's not that he's ruined the story, he just isn't DOING much with it.

B004QXJZXA|5.0|I and many others have written about the movie itself, but I'll just say a few words about the new BluRay DVD I just received yesterday.    Simpley put: well worth the money but a couple of odd results to mention.    For a very long time the only copy of this movie I had was a VHS tape I got off a cable channel that had used a horrible print. But I was one of few in country with a copy since no retail VHS was available.    Then, after several years of lawyers fighting, a VHS tape came out and I immediately buought it. But, sadly, it was still not great but better than the one I had. Then, after several more years a DVD came out and I bought it not that long ago (in comparison) and it was much better, especially using an upconverter DVD player and an HD tv.     With that said, I was very happy right off the bat with the BluRay. How one can tell is easy and done within the 1st minute or so when watching the intro section of the movie where McQueen drives his 911 to the track. This has always, photogenically/technically, been lackluster and always looked   \\"soft\\". Much, much better now but still looks a bit soft in sections compared to modern films.    I have come to the conclusion that the film crew/director were pushing the limits of film/light and as a result there is a fair amount of what we called back in the 60s/70s in the photo business \\"grain\\".  Some scenes suffer more than others. They'll be a slightly soft scene followed by a much better, sharper scene, like when he's thinking back on the crash the previous year. But BluRay really is great on close up pit and racing scenes and now a viewer can see the wrinkles in the side number \\"circles\\" on McQueen's 917.    Also, this was first time I played LeMans after installing a fiber optic audio cable in my soundbar. Great! Fiber optic cable is worth the money.  I got a GE one for $16.00 bucks at WalMart. Radio Shack wanted $39 for one.    The odd result with BluRay. The sky shimmers in the prerace scenes. Almost looks like rain. The sky is grainy and BluRay makes it stand out. But only really noticable in early scenes where there's a lot of sky. It looks like they were filming with an overcast and low light conditions. Remember, this is a film using 60s technology.    It is worth the not-so-cheap (as my wife said) cost. My wife also knows I own a DVD of the movie (as well as Grand Prix which I also ordered in BluRay).

B0015AARJI|1.0|Don't buy a PS3 controller from NorAm International Partners, Inc.  They are selling fake controllers.  You can tell it's fake if the buttons seem a little off, the home button and the LED lights at the top are a little recessed, and if you have difficulty syncing the controller to your PS3.  By difficulty, I mean that it takes 30 seconds or more to sync and flashes all four lights for this time.  Also, if your controller is plugged in when you shut your ps3 down, your controller will continue to blink and will actually restart your ps3, meaning you have you manually turn it off or unplug the controller.  Finally, the sticker on the back of the controller is missing most of the specs other controllers have on them.  Wish I would have read their feedback profile before I bought it, as this is not the first time someone noticed it was fake.  Don't buy from them, you'll regret it

B003Q6D1YW|4.0|Nev Schulman is a professional photographer in NYC who one day is contact via Facebook by a young girl from Michigan named Abby.  Abby is an aspiring artist, and she has made a painting from one of Nev's photos that was published in a national paper.  From this one painting (not a great painting, but darn good for an 8-year old)...Nev & Abby begin an online friendship, the results in many more paintings coming Nev's way, several phone conversations with Abby's mom and ultimately, an online romance with Abby's older sister Megan.    Via Facebook, texting and sporadic phone conversations, Nev discovers that Abby is becoming a commercially viable artist (he's excited that his paintings by Abby may be worth a pretty penny) and that he's falling in love with Megan.    Nev makes a surprise journey to Michigan to finally meet Megan and her family in person.  What he finds there is far from what he expected and is quite surprising and even disturbing to him.    What makes CATFISH an unusual viewing experience is that it is (seemingly) a documentary.  Nev is a real person, as are his filmmaker roommates:  his brother Ariel and their friend Henry Joost.  When the paintings by Abby start arriving, Nev is cajoled into letting these two guys document his emerging online relationships.    Nev makes a charming subject.  He's handsome, smart and charming.  He's clearly exciting by his new love affair.  And when suspicions that all is not as it seems begin to set in, we root for Nev.    I'm not telling you what they find in Michigan, because that's the big surprise of the film.  And it's also the big quandary in trying to evaluate this film.  If this is a 100% true, unmanipulated documentary, it serves as a chilling, funny and sometimes touching exploration of the dangers of online relationships and the ways modern society allows individuals to be things they aren't and represent themselves in manners different from reality.    But by pointing out how easy it is to manipulate folksthrough careful selection and manipulation (such as when a documentarian edits a film a certain way and chooses what footage to show and what to leave out)...we can't help but have a feeling at some level that CATFISH is a put-on.  It clearly isn't a complete fake...but have events been staged?  Has it been so edited as to not really represent a reasonable version of the truth?  I know philosophers say that the very act of recording an event changes it...but CATFISH is an outstanding illustration of this.    In brief, this \\"true\\" story is almost too good, too dramatic to be true.  We asked to believe that all this manipulation of the truth is merely being observed and that the filmmakers aren't manipulating it themselves.      That being said, these mind-bending quandaries make CATFISH a lot of fun.  It's a hoot wrestling with trying to figure out just what these people have in mind.  Nev seems like just a nice guy...but sometimes his observations are just so perfect, they feel scripted.  Ariel and Henry seem to ask Nev to do and say things for the benefit of their film, and not because he wants to do or say them.  And the folks in Michigan are a very colorful cast of characters, to say the least.    A sense of sadness permeates the film.  It's sad to think how Nev falls in love with a girl he's never met, when he lives in NYC, a city with a few \\"real\\" single women.  And the truth in Michigan is sad (I wish I could say more).      CATFISH is a fascinating curiosity.  It stimulates the intellect more than emotions.  If what I've described above sounds intriguing...by all means take a look.  If it sounds only like 90 minutes of east coast artiste navel-gazing...you will probably have your feelings validated.  In some ways, the far superior EXIT THROUGH THE GIFT SHOP explores some similar territory, but for me, CATFISH was still well worth a look.

030746363X|4.0|I checked out \\"The 4-Hour Body\\" from the library, having done the same months ago with \\"The 4-Hour Workweek,\\" so I knew to expect Ferriss's overcharged style. As a journalist myself, I've had hundreds of readers take issue with my articles, using comments like \\"why didn't you test with THIS?\\" or \\"how could you have possibly mixed up X with Y?\\" Such people seem so obsessive about displaying their superiority with minutiae that they completely miss the point of the story and fail to derive the help and knowledge I was trying to convey. I see that same sentiment riddled throughout these \\"4-Hour Body\\" comments. Come on, people, grow up. You want to argue about whether a female orgasm happens in the advertised 15 minutes versus 20? Or the fine points of glycemic conversion? Or how many angels can dance on the handle of a kettleball? The POINT is whether or not Ferriss sets you on the path to desired results. And for me, he did.  By happy coincidence, my months-long hold request for \\"The 4-Hour Body\\" came in right when a copy of Dr. Michael Eades's \\"The 6-Week Cure for the Middle-Aged Middle\\" also fell into my hands. The two authors came from very different directions and ended up saying much the same thing. I'm 40 years old, spawned from a gene pool that looks like a toxic vat of cancer, diabetes, and heart disease. When I read these books a month ago, I weighed 234 pounds (at 6' 0\\") and had blood work bad enough that my doctor wanted to prescribe statins.  I implemented the Ferriss diet plan on June 20th and deviated only slightly from it. For example, I got some plain, nonfat yogurt to mix with a few blueberries as a snack. Eades doesn't seem to object to dairy and low-sugar fruit in the same way that Ferriss does, so I went for a middle point between the two authors. Also siding with Eades, I went cold turkey on all caffeine and alcohol, figuring that if I was going to experience carb withdrawal (which I did for 2-3 days), why not throw caffeine on the fire, too? Butthe punchline is this: After 21 days on the plan, I had my blood drawn and analyzed. With effectively zero exercise, here is what happened:  1. Weight: 234 before, 221.5 after .. 12.5 lb. loss  2. Blood pressure: 132/83 before (averaged from many tests over weeks), 121/71 after [I have *never* had a reading this low in the past three years of measuring  3. Glucose: 93 before, 87 after  4. Total cholesterol: 192 before, 153 after  5. Triglycerides (the most important measurement to me): 228 high, 106 after  I had expected some improvement. I knew that statins (Lipitor, etc.) average a 15% drop in cholesterol and 20% drop in triglycerides (see [...]) after *many months* of use. But nothing had prepared me for the massive drop caused by this diet change -- a change that has me eating 3-4 whole eggs plus bacon plus other meats every day and heaping my plate with vegetables at every meal. The hunger that pervades calorie counting doesn't exist here.  Weight loss is fine, but THIS...this was a new lease on life. This meant that by turning my back on the mass-produced, over-marketed, sugar-and-carb extravaganza that comprises the modern American diet, I just might be free from the decades of torture I've seen my parents and grandparents endure.  I'll visit my doctor in a few days to get more details on my blood work, and I'm very curious to examine LDL and uric acid levels. (Some people caution that a high-protein diet can spike uric acid, which in turn can lead to gout.) But back to my original point, do I care if Ferriss is off on a few points? Heck, I don't care if he's off on 80% of his points. My job as an attentive reader is to identify the 20% of information that is most valuable and pertinent to my life and apply it for maximum benefit. As Ferriss advises, I did that here, then corroborated that 20% against outside reading from trusted authorities, and the results speak for themselves.  UPDATE: On December 14th, I crossed the line and hit my goal of losing 40 pounds. This was with weekly cheat days...OK, and maybe several extra cheat days thrown in along the way. Blood tests showed that my uric acid is slightly elevated, but otherwise everything looks very healthy. Since December, I've maintained at a 40-pound loss. I could probably stand to lose another 10 to 15 pounds, and I expect it will take a decrease in dairy and/or sucralose consumption as well as an increase in exercise to make this happen. Still, the modified Ferriss plan was sufficient to get me where I wanted to go on its own.

B00005MNP8|5.0|`Parallel Lines' is now one of those mythic albums, cited as one of the best of all time by many a critic and punter, so much so that it has become an `establishment' record along the lines of Fleetwood Mac's `Rumours', Bruce Springsteen's `Born to Run' or Radiohead's `OK Computer (none of which, obviously, it resembles!). Part of the legend has also become the way in which Australian producer, Mike Chapman (Suzi Quatro, The Sweet, Nick Gilder) stepped into the production shoes, taking over from Richard Gottehrer (`[[ASIN:B00005MNP5 Blondie]]', `[[ASIN:B00005MNP9 Plastic Letters]]') to crack the whip and make Blondie muscle up and produce a real record.<br /><br />In reality, though he may have disciplined them behind the scenes, the magic of Chapman's production is that his approach gave them only a slightly slicker, more commercial sound. The real achievement is that he allowed this record to sound like a natural progression from `Plastic Letters', released the year before (which was a marked step up from their debut), and recorded a band that still sounded exactly like themselves - like Blondie. Granted, `Heart of Glass' (it is the glossier `disco version' here, which replaced the first version on the original pressing of `Parallel Lines' a short time after its release) and to a lesser extent, Chris Stein's sickly pure pop confection, `Sunday Girl', interrupt the album's stylistic flow. But even the first two Blondie records showed a formative predilection for genre hopping.<br /><br />Unlike the first two albums, there is no real filler here and all band members, save drummer Clem Burke, contribute to song-writing. Lyrically witty, it features some of the band's most beautiful lines and turns of phrase. It opens intoxicatingly with the short punk onslaught of Jack Lee's `Hanging on the Telephone' and later features another similar composition of his, `Will Anything Happen'. Both of these tracks completely compliment the style in which the band wrote for the album. Despite the well known hits, some of the very best songs and highest points on the record were not singles. Chris Stein's hauntingly slow and dirgey `Fade Away and Radiate' is utterly stunning, as is Jimmy Destri's mod pop rocker, '11:59'. Along with `Picture This', it is the closest thing to the style of the first two discs. `Pretty Baby' (Harry/Stein) is another hypnotic, 60s styled new wave moment. `One Way or Another' and `I Know But I Don't Know' ensure the playful tongue-in-cheek quotient that the band had already established is not missing. The closest thing to a weak point is the somewhat superfluous Buddy Holly cover, `I'm Gonna Love You Too'.<br /><br />`Parallel Lines' is their most famous record, but despite its reputation, it doesn't mean the band were never able to eclipse it They would with 'Eat to the Beat' the following year. This 2001 remaster sounds excellent but the 4 bonus tracks again don't add anything (particularly the terrible live version of T-Rex's `Get It On').m. Despite the well known hits, some of the very best songs and highest points on the record were not singles. Chris Stein's hauntingly slow and dirgey `Fade Away and Radiate' is utterly stunning, as is Jimmy Destri's mod pop rocker, '11:59'. Along with `Picture This', it is the closest thing to the style of the first two discs. `Pretty Baby' (Harry/Stein) is another hypnotic, 60s styled new wave moment. `One Way or Another' and `I Know But I Don't Know' ensure the playful tongue-in-cheek quotient that the band had already established is not missing. The closest thing to a weak point is the somewhat superfluous Buddy Holly cover, `I'm Gonna Love You Too'.<br /><br />`Parallel Lines' is their most famous record, but despite its reputation, it doesn't mean the band were never able to eclipse it They would with 'Eat to the Beat' the following year. This 2001 remaster sounds excellent but the 4 bonus tracks again don't add anything (particularly the terrible live version of T-Rex's `Get It On').

Some of the music is quite enjoyable: The music heard while Alex visits the grave & where the statue has a tear of blood (this is at the cemetery at night where Alex first sees his girlfriend;s sister but disappears when she calls her dad, screaming that there's someone there), the music at the end where the final dialogue is heard (right before the end credits hit). They are on the score soundtrack as appears as: Alex Visits Lauren's Grave, Slo-Mo Walking, Love Theme - Ending. Listen to these 3 tracks.<br /><br />City Of Angels - This one while better than Salvation & Wicked Prayer still does not hold a candle to the original. Here, Vincent Perez stars in the lead role. Vincent's character is Ashe Corven, who's killed along with Danny, his son. Sarah from the original flm returns, older & played by another actor (Mia Kirshner). Corven is resurrected (which is witnessed by Sarah herself) & along with the guidance of thecrow & Sarah, he seeks vengeance on the criminals to murdered him & his son. Sarah paints his face & he gets black colored clothing & a motorcycle. After killing off the minions one by one, he returns to his grave so he can rest in peace.<br /><br />The Original Crow - THE BEST of the series & one of the BEST films in my lifetime & in the history of films. The late, great, ahead of his time, Brandon Lee gave a performance second to none & I cannot find the words to describe his portrayal. He was totally dedicated to this film. It was his BEST performance & this film made his career, which ended prematurely thanks to a tragic accident on set during the making of the film. I will not go into detail about it because it saddens me too much to do so & people who read this likely already know what happened. Everything about this film is really just magnificently amazing! And that's putting it mildly! The entire cast were great & fit the roles better than anyone I know. But the MVP is & always will be IMO Brandon Lee. It's tragic yet at the same time ironic that the film in which the lead character, Eric Draven dies & is also the film which was supposed to lead Brandon Lee to superstardom, perhaps beyond that the film I believe he was most dedicated to, is also the film where he passed during the making of it. In the film, Eric returns after his death. Too bad Brandon can't.<br /><br />Note: The Skull Cowboy is a character that does not appear in the film. But he was intended to & you can see him for a second or two in an extended version of a scene. You'll find out which one eventually. He witnesses Eric's resurrection or does the resurrecting. I'm not sure. But he's just there to explain certain things to Eric such as why he's come back, what his mission is. Also, he explains to Eric that he lost a portion of his powers because he went off mission for a time to talk Darla into being a mom again to Sarah & quit using morphine cause it's bad. In the extended edition of the Funboy scene, he stabs Eric, who screams. THe reason for that is Cowboy's explanation for Eric losing some power<br /><br />DVD Extras: Deleted footage montage (excellent bgm), Extended scenes, Making-Of Featurette (I love these kinds of extras. It's why I buy DVD's. This was a great one! Wish all the main cast members & crew were present for this. But it wasn't to be), and finally, Brandon Lee's very last interview (that was also on The Crow vhs).<br /><br />If you can find the dvd of the original alone & you should be able to, get it cause the movie & extras are definitely worth multiple viewings & I also recommend the score more than the soundtrack although the soundtrack does have some great songs on it. Both fit the film well especially the tracks that appear in the film. I thought they were heard in the movie at the right times & places. I don't know but I prefer the DVD's audio over the bluray. But the bluray has better picture quality & that is the reason I have both versions.

They have this ability called tuning which they use to move around the city that they built based on stolen memories. John woke up during the middle of an experiment so it was interrupted rather than be completed. Therefore he's left with fragments of memories & sets out to find out who he is. 0143038419|3.0|I came to the book via the movie, having seen the movie so many times that I felt I ought to read the book.  I can see why the producers of the film made the decisions they did and why the movie is so different than the book--different, but no less entertaining.  But this is about the BOOK.<br /><br />\\"Eat Pray Love\\" was mostly entertaining, somewhat informative, and by degrees uplifting and irritating; I looked forward to reading it every day, and as a result (against my better judgement) I ordered a copy of the sequel.  I've developed a habit, when I'm into a good read, of looking back to the cover, to the author's picture, as if that will give me any insight as to what's going on.  Elizabeth Gilbert is odd then, in that I could never match her face with the prose.  I went to the internet and saw other pictures, I still couldn't match the face to the character in the book.  Don't know why.  In any case, the book is a monologue, a long-winded, almost stream-of-consciousness monologue that is all about Elizabeth and how Elizabeth can't seem to get a grip on herself.  She cries, she screams, she's a mess, and what the movie doesn't tell you, she's on anti-depressants, although, she doesn't like the idea and won't stay on them any longer than she has to--which is about half way through Italy.  Still, Elizabeth The Annoying Wreck (who would have driven people out of the theater in droves) has some very impressive moments of contact with the divine, and therein is where I found my connections with her, and thus her story.  As annoying as she is, whiney-whiney-whiney--she at least doesn't give up, she fights on, and she does it on various levels, from travel to spiritualism, and when necessary, prescription drugs.<br /><br />Some of the book reads like a self-help manual, with fluffy and often not necessarily well researched conclusions, like a reference to a New York Times article about Tibetan monks hooked to a machine while they meditated, and the machine seeing theirbrains go from the normal red/yellow/orange levels of activity, to a cool blue that coalesces into a \\"blue pearl\\".  Go to the internet and look up that meditation study, and you can see the same brain scans and there is no all-blue brain, let alone a blue pearl, just a blue-center brain with bright fringes.  Close, but would you really want to make policy based on this, and then take it on the road where Fox news is going to rip you apart?  Accuracy may not be as much fun, but it builds credibility.<br /><br />And then, after four intense months in an Indian ashram, where she really came in contact with what ailed her, and made her whole, she flies to Bali, and one short plane ride later arrives worried that she won't be able to find her old friend Ketut, the medicine man.  Wouldn't the Universe take care of that?  This is a woman who meditated herself to a stormy beach for a lesson with a dead Yogi, and later was swept away (in meditation) to a brief moment in the palm of God's hand.  Didn't anything stick?<br /><br />Yet, as I thought, the Indian part of the book was my favorite, where the Indian part of the movie has become the part I most often skip over.  The movie is far more visual, and that part doesn't serve the camera as well as it's content carries and enlivens the book.<br /><br />One thing I didn't expect, and which I found quite pleasant every time she did it, was her way of bringing brief but detailed histories of places, activities, rituals or words into the narrative.  One moment she's approaching \\"air head blonde\\" in a really bad way, and the next minute she's telling you something you really ought to know, but that other writers wouldn't find germaine to the story and would skip, as a result.<br /><br />This book will not be for everybody.  Many--as the customer reviews attest--will find it all self centered whining and babble, and that is understandable.  But for those who have their own issues with getting themselves under control and are always looking for ideas, this is more entertaining than a run of the mill self help manual, and may well show you that some people are even a bigger mess than you are.

I can only watch this series on DVDs because it is such a great show that if I watched the series weekly I would not be able to contain myself if I had to wait to see the next episode.  I know it's a bummer to wait it out so long but to be able to watch as many episodes as I want without commercial interruption is worth it. Yep, it's that good.  If you haven't already, get season one and two and curl up on the sofa and treat yourself to some fine TV.

0553801473|5.0|INTRODUCTION: As I mentioned in other posts, there are only two authors that I regard as iconic in fantasy and one of them is George Martin since before A Game of Thrones appeared - and especially before it started taking off in the late 90's, early 00's - I found very little genre fantasy to read. I am not a Tolkien, Feist, D&D, Jordan, Erikson, etc fan since I prefer my fantasy to be with little magic and closer to historical fiction - my main problem with magic is that it suffers from the \\"works at one clock, but not at two a clock\\" syndrome as well as the authors rarely exploring the implications on societal evolution of having unambiguous, \\"I can kick it\\" proof of mind's ability to influence matter directly, not through technology and science.<br /><br />Before AGoT, I knew about Mr. Martin from his awesome Sandkings novella which was one of the defining texts of my childhood that made me a lifelong sf fan, so intrigued by the blurb I bought AGoT on release and never looked back, while thinking, that, \\"yes, this is the fantasy I want to read\\". On the other hand I do not tend to agonize over unfinished series and I read the books as they come, so after A Feast for Crows and the rereads of the earlier three books in 2005, I kind of forgot about ASoIaF until this year's superb TV series put me back in a Westeros mood and I've reread the four earlier books.<br /><br />So very, very high expectations for A Dance with Dragons and after the first two reads, I have to say that the book while not perfect and quite transitional and expanding the story-lines rather than starting to pull them together as one would expect in a fifth out of seventh series novel, delivered more than enough to be my top fantasy of the year so far.<br /><br />In the following I will try to avoid major spoilers for the novel itself, though there will be of course major ones for the series up to AFFC and as befitting a novel of such huge scope with action taking place in many locales, lots of characters, etc, the \\"review\\" will be more of a collection of impressions and highlights, as well as some of the stuff I thought worked less well. As usual, whatever counts as spoiler for a person may not count as such for me, so if you have not read A Dance with Dragons so far, read what follows at your peril!<br /><br />OVERVIEW/ANALYSIS: The first thing that surprised me when reading A Dance with Dragons is that the book does not have the \\"each word counts\\" finished feel I expected after the very public six year struggle of the author with it; for the first 600 pages I felt like almost nothing happens as the big picture goes, just going back and forth to mark the time until the timeline gets to the end of A Feast for Crows and things can start happening; when things start to happen, yes the action is mostly awesome, but there is some silliness too.<br /><br />Now, \\"almost nothing happens\\" would be an indictment for many authors since it would mean bloated verbosity, but in GRRM's case, the world building, the character dialogue and the nuggets of action that we see are more than enough to make the pages turn by themselves and keep one absorbed.<br /><br />Yes, not all story-lines are equally absorbing and for me the North alternates between very interesting when we see the actions of various Northern lords, most notably the Boltons and lord Manderly in the new circumstances, while Stannis prepares to assert his rule and confront his enemies and the more boring parts of Jon trying to be \\"humane\\" and integrate the starving, fleeing wildlings with their historical enemies, the Night Watch whose commander he happens to be. Never a big favorite of mine, I have to say that \\"Lord Snow\\"'s arc is one of the best realized in the book and it will be a highlight for many.<br /><br />Or Tyrion's wanderings where maybe because of him being still in shock after the dramatic events of A Storm of Swords, he is far from the sharp operator we got to know and love and seems more like acomic relief persona thrown there to be blown away on the wind by whatever current is stronger at the moment. This was the part I was looking forward the most and maybe because of that, it was the most disappointing thread of the novel.<br /><br />The other main story of the novel, Daenerys' rule of Meereen is quite interesting though, even if it is not what what is generally assumed that happens in fantasy - where the destined one comes, conquers, snaps his/her fingers and all live happily ever after. No, here we see \\"reality\\": conquering with a strong army and better weapons is easy, but holding on what you conquer is very hard and requires sacrifices; this point of \\"is it worth to conquer hoping to give people a better life, only to realize that most want the lives they led before and having peace may mean compromising all you hold dear?\\" that we see repeated throughout history up to the present, is one that GRRM keeps making and as mentioned above there is no \\"out of jail card\\". I found this thread excellent and very realistic though I am sure that people wanting traditional fantasy will hate it the most.<br /><br />Daenerys' peregrination and decisions were simple so far - she acted true to her principles and despite hardships she has won - but now that she decided to actually rule, she faces two equally unheroic choices: bath Meereen in the blood of her enemies, including the hostages from her entourage that she came to like, or compromise with the slavers and their allies and allow a more relaxed form of what came before. And the way this dilemma plays through the book was to me one of the highlights of the novel; without easy choices, the author's handling of it was as good as possible within the constraints.<br /><br />Interspersed with these three main stories, there are a lot of other characters stories and those mostly work well, but here and there I was wondering at the structure of the novel and how quite a few of those (Bran and Cersei's chapters forexample and maybe even Arya's) could have easily been included in A Feast for Crows since they are tangential to this book, while leaving space for expanding the intrinsic stories of A Dance with Dragons and sparing us the \\"unfinished feel\\" we get in the end, feel which the author clearly indicated was due for lack of space.<br /><br />A Dance with Dragons is not short on great lines and there are quite a few scenes that hold with the best to date in the series but I will leave that for everyone to discover them. For myself, besides the obvious ones, Cersei's arc was quite memorable for example especially still having clear in mind Lena Hadley's arrogant but great performance of the queen in the TV series...<br /><br />As for characters, for me the best one - in the heroic fantasy mode - was Ser Barristan who has several POV chapters and he is given ample scope to show why he is so famous after all. The most disappointing one was Tyrion as mentioned above.<br /><br />Now for the things that worked less well - I think that Mr. Martin's decision to split the story geographically rather than chronologically was misguided and A Dance with Dragons shows it since until the timeline catches with AFFC, nothing major we do not know about can happen and this - what I call the prequel's bane - makes those first 600 pages or so much slower than the rousing finale.<br /><br />The wrap up to most stories is another issue - here the culprit is the page count which basically forced the author to postpone lots of events to the next book - so there is a feel of incompleteness and while it bothers me less than others, I think that will be easily seen as the major shortcoming of the novel. The good news is that once The Winds of Winter will be out, this aspect will be forgotten, the bad news is that we have no idea when that book will be out...<br /><br />And here we come to the last thing of concern, namely that at the current pace, I have a hard time seeing it finished in two more volumes, even of 1000 pages like this one. Now that is not a bad thing since I am happy to read at length about the wonderful characters of GRRM and their world, but one thing I hope is that the author will not try again to be over ambitious and stick with a \\"I said seven, seven must be\\" plan and then realize he simply does not have the space to tell all the stories he wants, the way he wants. When in a fifth out presumably seventh book and in 1000 pages+, the story and characters expand, sometimes quite a lot, rather than starting to get together, this is something one has to mention.<br /><br />Overall I think that if you are an obsessive fan who discusses the finest points of the series in great detail in various forums, the book will be acceptable but not totally awesome for the reasons mentioned above, but if you love a grand scale epic series where the author keeps his \\"action have consequences and there is no get out the jail card\\" stance that so shocked people including myself in the earlier volumes, A Dance with Dragons (A++) will be the one novel you want to read this year indeed!<br /><br />Note; this review has been published first on Fantasy Book Critic and all links and references are to be found there

B004Y1USV2|4.0|Recently I tried to think of as many bands as I could that if they were to make a new album or come to town with a show, how many would contain the groups original lineup.  The answer was almost none. So I came to the conclusion that the only real way to judge a new release was to be not too concerned about the current lineup and also not to obsess about whether what the band is currently doing sounds exactly like something they may have done 30 years ago!  I grew up listening to Yes in the 70's and saw them in 1972 and then again in 2004 (both times original line-up both times great)  I will always love Yes 70's output through \\"Going for the One\\". I really haven't been blown away by anything they have put out since, except maybe Drama and some of Keys to Ascension.  But I'm glad they have continued because they are still phenomenal live and each record has moments of great Yes music.  I had no idea Yes was working on a new record and when I heard about it I was not expecting much.  I feel as though on records like \\"The Ladder\\" and \\"Magnification\\" Jon has gone from being a visionary to unfortunately a singer of bland New Age sentiments.  Not awful but kind of weak in my opinion.  I actually heard part of Fly from Here before I even knew that Jon was no longer in the band.    So now I have heard FFH 4 times and I am somewhat surprised and cautiously hopeful for this one.  There is I guess nothing wrong with judging a piece of art a few days after it has been released but it is a fact that time will be the real judge here.  Somethings rise while others fall with the passing of time.    My first impression of FFH is that it is a proper Yes album.  It has a 20 minute epic, a Steve Howe solo guitar piece and the right kind of album artwork.  And I am thrilled to say that it sounds like an old school Prog Album!!! However, it doesn't sound exactly like an old school Yes Prog album.  But, at least in my opinion this is an interesting development.  I'm hearing hints of KingCrimson, Pink Floyd, Kansas, Asia, along with Drama era no Jon Anderson in the music and since none of those groups are really doing this any more it may not be a bad idea for Yes to carry the Prog torch since in my mind they are the best at it anyway.  FFH may be a bit too MOR but at least so far all the music seems a good representation of this sound/style.  The music is very uplifting without being sappy and too new agey.    Apparently Benoit David was involved in a Yes tribute band and at times he sounds just like Jon singing.  I can't help but think that the injection of young blood has been really good for this new Yes record.  He does not drop the ball once, during the whole of the record and I think he deserves a lot of praise for this and maybe for fans of Yes music a new Star has been born. Two thumbs UP!!!
B004LWZW24|1.0|This movie is an absolute joke of a plot and is one of the most pathetically written storylines I have ever seen. If the \\"Time Travelers Wife\\" and \\"The Exorcist\\" had a baby together, it would be called INSIDIOUS.    I like watching horror movies for entertainment value and normally do not care much about storyline or flow, but that is where Insidious totally screws up - its presented in a way you are expected to take it seriously. It tries to walk the same lines as \\"The Exorcist\\" or \\"Exorcism of Emily Rose\\" which relates directly to possession but Insidious has it's own twist  with the idea of astro-travelers.    Insidious begins on the right foot building up tense and scary moments as the family moves into a new house and 'odd' things start to happen. It really does do things right in terms of instilling that creepy feeling into the viewers early on. The first half of the movie you are constantly wondering why happened to their son and what is all this strange stuff that is happening.     THEN, it totally nose-dives into a rushed explanation, ridiculous, almost laughable turn when they move into the second house. As soon as the psychic lady strapped on the gas mask to `cross to the other side' I quickly realized this movie was a total joke. I was waiting for the rest of Slipknot to come out and start playing `Wait and Bleed' (only metal fans will get this joke). I will cut the writers some slack on moronic `astro traveler / out of body experience' stuff but the way this `astro traveler' garbage plays out was just absurd and I found myself laughing more than once during these parts. Astro travelers can jump in and out of `the further/other side,' battle the bad guys in fist-a-cuffs, save cute little kids from Darth Maul looking `fire demons,' then wonder aimlessly in the dark with a kids Coleman lantern looking pathetic, but just have to `follow the voice' to go ahead and jump back to the real world. Perhaps it would have been better if the writers included ruby redslippers that you click together and just say `there is no place like home' to transport back. At this point in the film I was expecting anything absurd, so this would have fit right in.    I put Insidious up there as one of worst horror movies I have ever seen, right next to JEEPERS CREEPERS.
B003Y5H542|4.0|Rango is a different type of animated film, to say the least. It resembles a classic Western - with the new Sheriff, self-dealing mayor, and wretched citizens - more than it resembles anything Pixar has put out. The characters curse and can be downright grim. In short, this isn't a kid's movie.     If you can get beyond that fact, Rango is pretty entertaining. It has two great strengths. First, the animation is exceptional - easily the best I've ever seen. The hair and scales on the animals looks eerily real. At times I even wondered if ILM had inserted real animals into the film, particularly for the Hawks and Snakes.    Second, the characterization of Rango - the little green chameleon - becomes a more convincing and complex character than those found in many live-action Westerns. He begins as almost a Don Quixote type character, starts telling tall tales, and soon finds himself forced to respond to events. He never quite loses his inner doubts, but he also clearly possesses an inner strength. It's a joy to watch him grow. In addition, the film has some genuinely funny moments, mostly with Rango at the center.    Despite this, my criticism of the film is precisely the same one pointed out by so many other reviewers here: the film seems to want to appeal to adult and child audiences at the same time, but doesn't really succeed in doing this. So much of the film - the language, the allusions to Western classics, the grim ambience - is geared towards adults, that the more childlike scenes - particularly the cartoonish battle royale at the end - are all the more jarring.     Overall, if you're an adult or older kid who likes animated films, Rango's worth checking out.

B0000683DH|5.0|Star Trek: The Motion Picture(1979) was a minor success at the box office. The studio was willing to green light a sequel with a lower budget of $11 million and most of the creative control was given to writer/producer Harve Bennett. Gene Roddenberry had an idea for Star Trek II where Klingons would go back in time and prevent the assassination of John F. Kennedy, but the movie studio didn't give approval. In Star Trek II: The Wrath of Khan(1982), Khan(Ricardo Montalban) and his followers escape from a planet colony and steal the Starship Reliant. Khan Noonien Singh was the bad guy in the Star Trek episode 'Space Seed'. Khan also steals the Genesis Torpedo; it's a terraforming device that can be used as a weapon. Admiral Kirk(William Shatner) takes command of the Enterprise when Space Station Regula doesn't respond. Star Trek II: The Wrath of Khan is dark and violent, but it's also action-packed and thrilling. It was well-made considering the limited budget. Director Nicholas Meyer(Time After Time) adds a swashbuckling sense of adventure into the film. The late Merritt Butrick is quite good as Kirk's son, David. He gives an earnest performance and doesn't \\"phone in\\" the role. This film has the famous catchphrase yelled by Kirk, \\"KHAAAAAAAN! KHAAAAAAAAAN!\\" James Horner(Aliens, Wolfen) wrote a good music score for Star Trek II and III.   Star Trek II started a story arc that completes itself in Star Trek IV: The Voyage Home(1986). This film has an unpleasant scene where Khan puts a Ceti Alpha eel in Chekov's ear! Some clever stop motion, animation, and cloud tanks were used to keep the special effects budget under control. The models for the USS Enterprise and the USS Reliant were filmed with VistaVision and Dykstraflex Cameras. Some early computer animation was used for the Genesis Torpedo video. The Starfleet Uniforms were redesigned to look more like naval uniforms. They were made with red/burgundy cloth. The critical and box office success helped to renew interest in Star Trek in 1982. Star Trek III: The Search for Spock(1984) continues where this film leaves off.
0062060554|5.0|I was drawn to this book because of the premise.  What must it be like to awaken each morning and have to relearn your life?  Where are you?  Who is the man sleeping next to you?  How did you get here?      A \\"tragic accident\\" robs Christine Lucas of her memories.  She wakes each morning unable to remember the last twenty years of her life.  She has a rare form of amnesia that erases her memories as she sleeps each night.  Every morning she wakes up unaware of her surroundings, her husband a stranger, her life a mystery.  Each morning her husband must convince her that she is 47, not 29.  He must remind her that they are happily married and he his not a stranger.  With the help of a daily journal, Christine begins to piece together the fragmented memories of her life and begin to learn who she is now as well as who she was.      The story is told primarily through the journal that Christine has written.  The reader is unraveling her history and mysteries alongside Christine as she reacquaints herself with her memories.  What caused her amnesia?  Who is telling her the truth about her life?  Does she even want to know the truth each day?  Why would she see a doctor, but not tell her husband?  How can she know what is a true memory and what is her imagination trying to fill-in the blanks of her life?  Is someone hiding things from her or is she becoming paranoid?   When you can't remember who you are who can you trust?  Can you even trust yourself?  All of these questions and more form the basis for a thrilling, psychological ride.  The pages practically turn themselves as the questions pile up.  The reader feels as confused and terrorized as Christine as various aspects of her life come to light.  The heart-stopping conclusion left me as blind-sided as Christine.      I'll definitely be waiting for Watson's next novel!

I'll admit I'm not as huge a fan of Desplat's score for \\"Deathly Hallows, Pt. 1\\" as others, but I was intrigued by this set because of the extras that come with it. I managed to get my edition at a heavy discount, which made it far more desirable.     To detail what's included, I'll begin with the basics: the CDs. The first disc is the standard release that is available singularly. It comes with the booklet but no track listing, so if you intend to store it anywhere but the box itself you won't know what track you're on (a bad con and something Watertower Music should have thought through). The second disc includes more of the score from the film not included on the first disc, including a beautiful choral track titled \\"My Love Is Always Here\\", which is probably the best thing out of all of Desplat's work and well worth the extra price of buying the whole set alone. There is also a DVD with a 5.1 mix of the score and a behind-the-scenes look at the composing and scoring of it. The LP I can't vouch for as I have no record player to try it out on.     As for the other features, each box comes with a certificate stating the number of the edition, a mid-sized poster of the Trio running from Snatchers, a copy of a piece of sheet music, and a double film cell. I was very impressed with the latter, getting scenes from both \\"Hallows\\" films that were very well chosen and made getting this set worth the price.    All in all, I wish more had been included considering the high retail price, but I am pleased with the bonuses I received in getting this rather than the standard issue soundtrack.

0670022411|2.0|I can't say what bothered me the most about this story...was it the contrived romance between vampire and witch?  Perhaps the fact that about half of the storyline consists of explanations and not too much in the way of action?  Or is it that the main character spends an inordinate amount of time waiting for things to happen?       The story is about Diana Bishop, a witch who finds an enchanted manuscript that reacts strangely to her magic.  Due to this, she starts attracting the attention of a slew of other supernatural characters, many of whom are trying to obtain the manuscript from her and do her harm.  Diana also attracts the attention of a vampire named Matthew Clairmont and, of course, a relationship between them starts developing.   Sadly, this is where the story falls apart because of all the conversations.  In fact, that summarizes the whole book - characters talking to each other incessantly.  They talk about the taboo of a witch/vampire relationship, they talk about Diana's background, they talk about Matthew's background, they talk about the manuscript.  They talk and talk and talk throughout and, after a while, I started skimming through all the conversations, looking for juicier parts or hoping that the story would move along to no avail.  There are some great fantasies out there and you would be better served reading one of those.

B0010ZR160|4.0|After the success of Mystic River, I'd been hoping that someone would bring author Dennis Lehane's working-class PI team of Patrick Kenzie and Angie Gennaro to the screen. When Ben Affleck, of all people, did so for his first film as a director, he chose to film the fourth film in the series, Gone Baby Gone. 4-year-old Amanda McCready has disappeared, and her aunt brings in Patrick and Angie, who are from the neighborhood, to help with the case. It seems at first that the duo are successful at developing a lead, but readers of Lehane know that things are never what they seem on the surface in his stories. Ben Affleck does a good job in capturing the atmosphere, the complexity, and the moral ambiguity of Lehane's novel--he has more directing chops than I'd have expected.<br /><br />The cast is pretty good. Casey Affleck does a pretty good job as Patrick Kenzie, although he looks a little too boyish at times. Michelle Monaghan is also solid as Patrick's longtime friend and partner, and sometime lover, although she's limited by the way the script marginalizes Angie a lot of the time (the Angie of the books has a lot more fire in her). The supporting cast is excellent. Amy Ryan was, deservedly, Oscar-nominated as Helene McCready, Amanda's substance-abusing, self-absorbed mother. Also excellent are Ed Harris and Morgan Freeman as Boston PD heavyweights involved in the case, Titus Welliver as Lionel, Helene's brother, and rapper Slaine in a cameo as Patrick and Angie's sociopathic friend Bubba Rogowski. I'd love to see him return as Bubba if someone were to ever film any of the other Kenzie/Gennaro novels.<br /><br />There is a reasonable selection of extras on the DVD release: a couple of \\"making of\\" featurettes, some deleted scenes and an alternate ending, and a commentary from Ben Affleck and co-screenwriter Aaron Stockard.
B004K7HMJ6|3.0|'Who You Are' is Jessie J's appropriately titled first studio album. \\"Why\\", you might ask? Well, every studio artist is a product. Their image, sound, style, vibe, etc are all designed to appeal to a particular demographic and in Jessie's case I'm not quite sure what that demo is supposed to be. Her niche genre is unclear and includes everything from ballads about overcoming adversary to traditional uplifting uptempo pop tracks, topped with a big band number. I may have even detected some reggae/dancehall influence. That said, is this approach odd? Yes. Confusing? Yes. Refreshing? Very.<br /><br />Apparently, Jessie J is no stranger to writing hits and, in fact, co-wrote Miley Cyrus's 'Party in the USA' among songs for other artists such as Chris Brown. She shares writing credits on this album and, as mentioned elsewhere, in today's money/credit hungry corporate powered world, 'writing' credits aren't as viable as they once were. However, judging from her brilliant charismatic live performances, I'm inclined to believe Jessie J is the real deal. This is a solid first album and I believe there is enough talent here to garner an adequate fan base. As previously stated, it appears this album is an experimental introductory endeavor where Jessie J dons many musical hats in an effort to discover who she is as an artist.<br /><br />First off, the ballads drag the whole album down and the only one worth listening to is 'Big White Room', a live performance where Jessie's pitch perfect voice saves the day. The track is very stripped down and consists of just Jessie and a lone acoustic guitarist. I honestly had no idea this was live until the audience started applauding about 1/3rd of the way into the song. Her live voice really is that good and I wish she had better material, but I doubt this is the last we'll be seeing of the up and coming pop star. Give her time and I'm confident that her sound will evolve, but until then more lackluster tracks follow including 'Who's Laughing Now'. Jessie 'confronts' her tormentors via song, donning an uber mockney accent that really grates on my last nerve despite the fact that she's clearly parroting those who did her wrong. 'Do It Like A Dude' has a hip-hop/reggae heavy rhythm laced with rock guitar riffs; a love or hate track for sure. Personally, it doesn't work for me as I prefer to 'do it like a lady', but as an open bisexual perhaps this track is a not so subtle allusion to Jessie J's sexual proclivities? Well, 'Love', a bright even tempered pop track, definitely is and states as much: \\"Love doesn't choose a boy or a girl/when I met you you hugged my heart and filled my world\\". It appears Jessie's personality is as varied as her body of work.<br /><br />Lyrically, this album is not half bad. J is no Bob Dylan, but for a pop album there were instances where I was legitimately impressed. 'Price Tag', for instance, is co-written by Jessie herself and laments the music industry having taken a turn for the worst: \\"We need to take it back in time/When music made us all unite/And it wasn't low blows and video hoes/Am I the only one getting' tired?\\", not particularly original, but enjoyable just the same. 'Mamma Knows Best' is an invigorating big band/jazzy number and I hope she continues along this vein in the future, her voice certainly suits the style. Jessie has the ability to belt it out with the best of them; look out Lady Gaga, move over Beyonce! The song could  have easily tended towards her fellow UK songbirds (Amy Winehouse, Duffy, Adele, etc) and been more brooding and dark, but instead ended up a self-aggrandizing power anthem. Nice one, Ms. J!<br /><br />The album closes with the title track which is another underwhelming ballad bringing the final tally to about four (not including 'Big White Room') which is four too many. For the record, pop stars put far too much weight on ballads and they often end up being the weakest tracks on an album. I feel a solid pop album should have one or two ballads and that's only if they are stellar. Go big or go home. Ballads require a lot of raw emotion and should feel like it's coming from a real place, but usually ends up sounding like filler (which I loathe). This is really a criticism of pop music in general, but Jessie unfortunately manages to fall prey to this trap as well. If Jessie J nixed the paltry ballads this would easily have been a four star album, but I can only give it three (rounded down from 3 ). Overall, I'd say it's a promising debut and recommend it to anyone with an eclectic taste in music who's also looking for a breath of fresh air.hat's only if they are stellar. Go big or go home. Ballads require a lot of raw emotion and should feel like it's coming from a real place, but usually ends up sounding like filler (which I loathe). This is really a criticism of pop music in general, but Jessie unfortunately manages to fall prey to this trap as well. If Jessie J nixed the paltry ballads this would easily have been a four star album, but I can only give it three (rounded down from 3 ). Overall, I'd say it's a promising debut and recommend it to anyone with an eclectic taste in music who's also looking for a breath of fresh air.

B004ZZS4CC|5.0|Like many others, I read this in one sitting.  Indeed, it was tough to put down.  In the forward to the book, Jaycee says that this book was written in her own voice.  No, there were no fancy copy editors, no one to tell her to move things around, omit this or add that.  The fact that it WAS written in her own voice is what makes it so good.    The fact that this is a best seller is no mystery.  Too many people want to know what HAPPENED? And how did she deal with it?  Survive? And what is she like now?  For many, it is hard to understand how she could be in captivity and not try to escape--this book makes this very clear.  It is told in HER voice--with HER thoughts, so understanding that is easy once you've read it.  I cried.  A lot.  But this is also the tale of survival, and in that, it is truly inspirational.  How does someone get through even one hour, let alone that many years of horrible abuse?  Her strength is a true inspiration.  Jaycee, stay strong, go forth and have a wonderful life.

3832793836|4.0|I bought this book after seeing the amazing exhibition of Elliott Erwitt's photography at New York's International Center of Photography.    Erwitt's work is broad in scope, including more traditional photo journalism, as well as what would better be described as street photography. Much of his work takes scenes from everyday life and finds the irony and humour in them. There's a long-necked bird right next to a pipe sticking from the ground that forms the same shape as the bird. There's a woman in a market with two coconuts on a shelf placed exactly where her breasts would be. We see silhouetted people on a train platform, who appear to be African Americans, while an advertising sign promotes Griffin Allwite white shoe polish. There are numerous hilarious pictures of dogs, including one with a tiny chihuahua next to a woman's feet and the feet of a great dane, that are almost as big as the chihuahua itself.    This book is very complete. It contains all my favourite photos from the exhibition and many more.    I would rate this book a five except for one thing. Many of the photos span across both pages on the spread. In the paperback version, this means the centres of many photos get somewhat lost in the binding. I saw a hardcover version of this book at the exhibition, and in contrast, its pages could open very wide so that the full picture could be properly seen.    Overall though, this is a great book with the best work of one of the best photographers of all time.

B004USRKX8|3.0|I'll provide only a quick review here, so that others may avoid some purchasing confusion.
