031603441X|5.0|I LOVED this book.  It is 536 pages, and I enjoyed everyone of them.  I've read a lot of books, I am addicted to reading, I always have to have SOMETHING to read.  And I've read a lot of crap, and of course, a lot of really excellent material, and everything in between.  But I am SO GLAD that I took the time to read this book, it is excellent.    The fact that I am a musician, and a Rolling Stones fan from way back certainly doesn't make me an impartial judge.  But I stand by my assessment; excellent.    I never knew much about Keith except he was the BAD BOY, junkie, funky guitar player who supposedly had all his blood swithed out; like an oil change; in order to get off the junk (a fairy tale), and that he had his head smashed by a cocoanut when he was climbing a tree somewhere in the south Pacific (another fabrication).    I took all these lies to be truths; I thought Keith was just a lucky guy who happened to be Mick's guitar player, and song writing buddy.  I drank the kool-aid, I fell for the media hype; hook, line and sinker.    After reading this thoroughly entertaining book; I know Keith is someone I would love to be freinds with, even if he was just a poor guitar player who eked out a living playing in local bars.  Keith tells you his version of the truth so candidly, so bluntly, that you just believe it.    I'm sure that not evey single word is the truth, we're all human, and Keith surely did a little bit of spin control when telling his version of the crazy stories we've all heard.  But who you gonna believe? A guy that couldn't really give a hoot what anyone thinks, (and therefore has nothing to loose); or the MEDIA? Which hardly ever tells the truth when it comes to the lives of Rock Stars, Famous Actors and so forth.  The media lives for scandal.  So, I believe Keith.    By the end of the book you feel like you know this guy intimately, like you just made a new best freind.     Keef: Thanks for sharing with us, and thanks for all the great music. May you make beautiful music till you drop; because I know that is they way you'd prefer to live and die. Sincerely.
0553801473|2.0|Intro<br /><br />After the reading of ADWD I was so numbed by the outrage and disappointment that I was unable to identify the true reason for such feelings. That was six days ago, so I have substantially cooled down and managed to sort my impressions in the more rational fashion. My disappointment stems form my ill founded expectations, which are based on the quality of the first three books, almost eleven years of meager development of ASOIAF series, and neglecting the true proportions of catastrophic consequences of AFFC. I think I have found a more or less reasonable explanation for its present form, even its plausible purpose in ASOIAF series. And I still don't like it.<br /><br />Devil's advocate<br /><br />First of all, ASOIAF is projected as a seven book series, approximately 800 pages per book, so it is not realistic to expect ending of all major storylines (Tyrion, Dany, Jaime, Cersei, Bran, Arya, Sansa, Jon) sooner than the end of the seventh book. I'm pointing this out because many fans (myself included) have raised the question whether GRRM knows how to finish a storyline. He definitely does - the only problem is that most of the major storylines are going to span through entire series.<br /><br />As an aftermath of the war of five (or six?) kings, which ended with the ASOS, it was logical to cool down a bit and redeploy the major players for the upcoming Ice versus Fire clash. However, GRRM manage to make a huge mistake and seriously mess up ASOIAF series with that miserable decision to put the whole logistics into two books. Hence, instead of one OK book, he produced a 700 pages long boredom generator AFFC. In addition, GRRM managed to fail to deliver ADWD in 2006 - a cataclysmic mistake.<br /><br />As a consequence, he placed himself between hammer and anvil: on the hammer side, fans and publishers were constantly pushing him to finish, with increasing intensity as years has passed by; on the anvil side, AFFC has tied his hands with respect to the plot progression - he can go as far as the beginning of the winter.<br /><br />This unpleasant situation has sprouted some serious problems:<br /><br />1. The Others need winter in order to invade the North, so the principal conflict in the series cannot kick in. This considerably limits Jon's actions - he can just stay on the Wall and somehow try to increase the ranks of the Night watch. Recall that leaders of Westeros consider NW as a place to exile criminals and political opponents, not as actual defense against the ancient enemy (they actually believe that Others never existed and that the Wall is just an extravagance of Brandon the builder), so they have neglected the NW for a long time (at least decades, probably centuries);<br /><br />2. How to develop Dany? On the one hand, the book is titled \\"A dance with dragons\\", so it is pretty much mandatory to expect a large portion of the narrative devoted to Dany and her dragons. Besides, fans would probably demanded GRRM's head had he failed to deliver less than seven chapters on Dany. On the other hand, she cannot be expected in Westeros sooner that the last book, there is not enough time for some serious events (the upper limit is beginning of winter), so the reasonable number of chapters available for Dany is no more than three;<br /><br />3. The main characters of AFFC (Jaime, Brienne, Cersei, Sam, Arya, Sansa, Asha, Aeron, Areo Hotah and Victarion) can either be omitted, or barely mentioned - a consequence of their earlier development in AFFC and the time limit (beginning of winter).<br /><br />This time-limit obstacle has imposed difficulties with development of the other characters as well. Enough with advocacy, the time for trashing has come.<br /><br />Agent Bran<br /><br />Considering Bran, I am disappointed with the resolution of his journey to three-eyed crow. Firstly, the three-eyed crow is a man almost turned to a tree, which is too much Treebeardish for my taste. Secondly, Bran's greenseer training looks like rewriting of Neo's training in the Matrix: Bran eats wheirwood paste, which is a part of the plug-in process, they plant him in the \\"gear\\" and he starts to browse Matrix/wheirwood database of the past and present events. Combined with the skin-changer skills, he becomes \\"agent Bran\\" (in terms of technical performance of the agent Smith within the Matrix). I understand the logic behind this - Bran is the actual warden of the North and the Matrix-agent type of skills would facilitate this role perfectly. Still, I would be much, much happier with the substantially longer and more mystical/religious training.<br /><br />Parlor Mel<br /><br />Considering Mel, I'll start with the following quote:<br /><br />&lt;&lt; Food. Yes, I should eat. Some days she forgot. R'hllor provided her with all the nourishment her body needed, but that was something best concealed from mortal men.<br />...<br />While the boy was gone, Melisandre washed herself and changed her robes. Her sleeves were full of hidden pockets, and she checked them carefully as she did every morning to make certain all her powders were in place. Powders to turn fire green or blue or silver, powders to make a flame roar and hiss and leap up higher than a man is tall, powders to make smoke. A smoke for truth, a smoke for lust, a smoke for fear, and the thick black smoke that could kill a man outright. The red priestess armed herself with a pinch of each of them. The carved chest that she had brought across the narrow sea was more than three-quarters empty now. And while Melisandre had the knowledge to make more powders, she lacked many rare ingredients. My spells should suffice. She was stronger at the Wall, stronger even than in Asshai. Her every word and gesture was more potent, and she could do things that she had never done before. Such shadows as I bring forth here will be terrible, and no creature of the dark will stand before them. With such sorceries at her command, she should soon have no more need of the feeble tricks of alchemists and pyromancers.<br /><br />Martin, George R.R. (2011). A Dance with Dragons: A Song of Ice and Fire: Book Five (Kindle Locations 9148-9149, 9160-9168). Bantam. Kindle Edition.>><br /><br />I find this quite contradictory: R'hllor gives Mel complete nourishment, glimpses of the future, power to conjure shadows, probably power to raise the dead (Thoros of Myr has that power and I think that Mel is more solid in faith than Thoros), steady growth in power, and jet she needs cheap parlor tricks during her worship and sermons? From my point of view, this is a material mistake (both GRRM's and editorial) in the portraying of Mel. I see Mel as a powerful cleric of R'hllor and would expect her consistent development in that direction.<br /><br />Sookie Targaryen<br /><br />Considering Dany, I think that GRRM has failed miserably. As I said before, Dany cannot be expected in the Westeros before the seventh book and AFFC has tightly tied GRRM's hands with respect to the plot progression (he can go as far as the beginning of the winter, no further). As a consequence, I don't see any reason (from the overall plot point of view) to give more chapters to Dany than to Arya or Bran. Three chapters would serve the purpose quite well. GRRM chose to stretched the logical development from three to ten chapters. I don't like the result: this Meereen version of Dany reminds me of Sookie Stackhouse - a cute, incredibly stupid blonde from the HBO True Blood show. Now I'm unable to think of Meereen version of Dany as Daenerys Targaryen, but as Sookie Targaryen. Yuck!<br /><br />The narrative<br /><br />Let me put it bluntly - the book has around 500 pages more than the actual events covered in it deserve. As a consequence, instead of reasonably OK 500 pages book, we have been served with a supreme generator of boredom, a masterpiece on stalling, a PhD on dragging and meandering, a slap in the face, a heap of dung, a catastrophic failure.<br /><br />Conclusion<br /><br />If I have to compare ADWD with AFFC, then my vote goes to AFFC since it is significantly shorter. Of course, the last two installments of ASOIAF series have seriously chipped the overall quality. I think that the main reason is a lousy decision to split the entire logistics in two books. The only remedy is that GRRM majorly revise this two books and merge them into a single book with the upper limit of 800 pages (of course, that's not going to happen).<br /><br />Can I recommend ADWD? Barely, with the following warnings:<br /><br />1. Don't by it unless you want to a priori support GRRM's work. Otherwise, you'll probably feel cheated (after you finish the reading);<br /><br />2. Be careful about your expectations: ADWD will advance the plot only to the beginning of winter, no further. This genuinely small advance is heavily stretched on 1000 pages.of the feeble tricks of alchemists and pyromancers.<br /><br />Martin, George R.R. (2011). A Dance with Dragons: A Song of Ice and Fire: Book Five (Kindle Locations 9148-9149, 9160-9168). Bantam. Kindle Edition.>><br /><br />I find this quite contradictory: R'hllor gives Mel complete nourishment, glimpses of the future, power to conjure shadows, probably power to raise the dead (Thoros of Myr has that power and I think that Mel is more solid in faith than Thoros), steady growth in power, and jet she needs cheap parlor tricks during her worship and sermons? From my point of view, this is a material mistake (both GRRM's and editorial) in the portraying of Mel. I see Mel as a powerful cleric of R'hllor and would expect her consistent development in that direction.<br /><br />Sookie Targaryen<br /><br />Considering Dany, I think that GRRM has failed miserably. As I said before, Dany cannot be expected in the Westeros before the seventh book and AFFC has tightly tied GRRM's hands with respect to the plot progression (he can go as far as the beginning of the winter, no further). As a consequence, I don't see any reason (from the overall plot point of view) to give more chapters to Dany than to Arya or Bran. Three chapters would serve the purpose quite well. GRRM chose to stretched the logical development from three to ten chapters. I don't like the result: this Meereen version of Dany reminds me of Sookie Stackhouse - a cute, incredibly stupid blonde from the HBO True Blood show. Now I'm unable to think of Meereen version of Dany as Daenerys Targaryen, but as Sookie Targaryen. Yuck!<br /><br />The narrative<br /><br />Let me put it bluntly - the book has around 500 pages more than the actual events covered in it deserve. As a consequence, instead of reasonably OK 500 pages book, we have been served with a supreme generator of boredom, a masterpiece on stalling, a PhD on dragging and meandering, a slap in the face, a heap of dung, a catastrophic failure.<br /><br />Conclusion<br /><br />If I have to compare ADWD with AFFC, then my vote goes to AFFC since it is significantly shorter. Of course, the last two installments of ASOIAF series have seriously chipped the overall quality. I think that the main reason is a lousy decision to split the entire logistics in two books. The only remedy is that GRRM majorly revise this two books and merge them into a single book with the upper limit of 800 pages (of course, that's not going to happen).<br /><br />Can I recommend ADWD? Barely, with the following warnings:<br /><br />1. Don't by it unless you want to a priori support GRRM's work. Otherwise, you'll probably feel cheated (after you finish the reading);<br /><br />2. Be careful about your expectations: ADWD will advance the plot only to the beginning of winter, no further. This genuinely small advance is heavily stretched on 1000 pages.

B0030Y11XS|5.0|This film showed what irreversible damage has been done to our society and its people  by the venal few, when allowed free reign and without regulation. There are some wonderful points made. Moore gives numerous and fascinating vignettes of the tragic consequences of the powerful and greedy on ordinary lives. He comes over as a believer in the original principles of the founding father's of America, and in the principles that guide christian belief. He quite rightly plays the innocent abroad,a man curious to find out the truth - only because it is an effective way to communicate without layering the whole film with a personal diatribe of 'his own views'. He lets us make up our minds based on evidence we might not have been aware of before.       His repeated call at the end of the  film for 'us' to \\"DO SOMETHING\\" was spot on. I particularly liked the point about the scientist, Salk,  who discovered the Polio vaccine and refused to patent it for his own self interest. He could have been hugely wealthy, but rightly, gave the vaccine to the State to serve the people and save lives.  He personified the kind of rare selflessness that humanity needs now and much more than we might recognise.      I have come to really appreciate Michael Moore.  His stuff is deadly serious delivered under the guise of the questioning buffoon. It is brave, well researched, and deeply moving. He knits together a story of corporate greed and Government simony, with the dreadful impacts on individuals lives-particularly the voiceless poor. He uses eclectic examples which at first you don't think can be relevant, but successfully shows how unchecked Capitalist greed reaches into all areas of society. For example -he highlights news stories that pass by so rapidly in today's fast news agenda, to pull together the most damning indictment of the system's failure and horrors. There is the young people's correctional institution which makes the point so well. Here we are introduced to an $8 millionfacility, leased to State authorities. Moore interviews four young people, stunned and damaged by their experiences. Many of them were locked up for three times as long as their sentence allowed for minor infringements for which they should have only received a telling off. We meet vulnerable young people who were locked up for smoking a joint, or the girl who created a website that criticised the deputy head teacher at her school. They were locked up by a corrupt judge who lengthened sentences at will. They were sent to this private, for-profit correctional institution because the Judge was paid. The judge got paid for sending them customers!!! This was child abuse. It was stunningly shocking. Then we had the life insurances taken out on workers' lives by companies. They benefited from workers' deaths.      There were a few stories of co-operative working which lifted the spirits -the co operative bakers and other workers facing unemplpyment, who showed how things could be done differently.      The spotlight turned to the banks and their relationship with Government. The behaviour of the democratic party in supporting the Republican led $70 billion bailout was exposed. Paulson, Goldman Sachs, and their control of the Executive in Government still leaves me speechless however many times I hear about it. The stream of foreclosures, through state after state- were spotlighted. We saw the despair of the sick, elderly small farmer , encouraged to refinance who finds his payments doubling then tripling. He is evicted with nowhere to go. We see how refinancing was packaged and sold by such companies as Countrywide. The former farmer and his wife earn their last dollars by empyting their own home for the finance company who had sold it to someone else. It was cheaper for the company if the evicted couple cleared the house than to hire a professional house clearance company. The couple desperately needed the small amount of money this brought. This was a lesson in the ultimate humiliation which rampant greedy Capital and its officials are prepared to deliver. Talk about putting the boot in. Truly heartbreaking.   These tragic stories are countered with stories of fighting back. (We see the homeless Miami family taking over an empty property backed by community support.) But the fighting back has not really begun in earnest yet.     People talk about Moore being wealthy now from making movies.  I am glad he is wealthy. He can use the money to make more movies. He is still of the people. Money can often divorce people from their roots, but that hasn't happened to Moore yet. He is still the only one making populist rather than elitist documentaries that successfully communicate with the many. That Michael Moore was able to make this movie in America gives hope. Made in 2009, it needs updating, particularly on Obama's hands being tied by Capital's lobbying powers.     Moore offers a more popular and accessible overview of derivatives. It is an everyman's guide,which is necessary. He does it very well. ( For a clearer focus on the causes of the financial crash and the individuals in banks and their links with Government, see 'Inside Job'. This is a very good fast-paced and detailed doc made in 2010 which looks at the causes of the failures and on the actions of bankers and their friends in Government. It takes a more detailed look at packaged derivatives, Credit Default Swaps, Credit Default Obligations and Ratings agencies).       Many Americans have been brainwashed into believing that Socialism equals Communism and that Stalin was a socialist. Socialism has always meant Capitalism with a social face. What is wrong with that? There were a lot of people in this programme who caused this crisis and who actually loathe socialism because it shares out profits. (There is one rich man who says on camera that he won;t give up a piece of his pie. \\"I want all my pie\\" he says. I hope it chokes him.  Socialism is not an economic system. Capitalismis. But Capitalism can only survive if it serves the interests of all people not a few as we are now seeing. Capitalism can't survive in a country that has ever increasing unemployment and low wages. Who buys the goods?     The sovereign debt crisis has not played out yet. That will be the next chapter in Capital's crisis. More Moore of this kind of vintage please.

1451629184|4.0|To hear this story told by the little girl who lived it illustrates better than anything I've read how monsters like Phillip Garrido actually groom their victims to do their will.  For those who ask, \\"Why didn't she just run away,\\" I say read Jaycee's account of the days, weeks, years of physical, emotional and sensory deprivation that stole away her own will. Jaycee's account or the challenge of trying to overcome those lost years and regain the person she was meant to be is inspiring.  I found it fitting that the somewhat childlike writing at the beginning gives way to more adult perspectives as the book proceeds, just as the little girl grows into a woman.  I thank Jaycee for sharing her life in this way.  Her account is bound to help others understand how to help those who have lived through such a horrendous experience.  She thanks her rescuers, therapist, family and others for their participation in her recovery.  I'd like to say thank you too.  I'm glad you people exist and are willing to help.  It is proof, that unlike Phillip Garrido's view of the world, most of us are here to support rather than exploit and love rather than use. Best of luck to Jaycee and her family.

B004EPYZPS|4.0|Every now and then, a film comes along and reminds you of the way it used to be. Back in the eighties, blockbusters were made with heart. Everything from the acting to the direction was top-notch, especially if the film in question was a Spielberg film. Steven Spielberg is one of the best film directors in the industry. His love of the medium shines in just about every project that he has been a part of. Some of the most influential films of the past have his name attached to them, namely E.T., Close Encounters of the Third Kind, and Jurassic Park. He deals with fantastical themes with a heartfelt, childlike curiosity - a definite trademark that appears in many of his films. Recently, director J.J. Abrams made a film which can be seen as a love letter to Spielberg. This film is `Super 8', and it is one of the best offerings of the summer, as well as one of the best films of the year. And, for those of you who have followed me over the past two years, the mere fact that I am glowing over a mainstream blockbuster is nothing short of a miracle.     The film opens in Lillian, Ohio in 1979, and follows a group of close-knit boys during summer break, as they attempt to film a zombie flick with a Super 8 camera. Young Joe Lamb has recently lost his mother in a steel mill accident, and as a way to cope with his loss, he vows to help his best friend, the film-obsessed Charles, complete his latest cinematic masterpiece. Together with three other boys, and his latest crush, Alice, Joe slowly begins a journey of self-discovery. Everything changes one night during a film shoot, when the boys witness, and barely manage to escape, a horrific train wreck. The kids flee the site, as the U.S. Air Force arrives.    This leads to strange phenomena in the town; pets running away from their owners, the disappearance of car engines and power lines, and people being abducted. Soon after, the boys discover some disturbing footage which was caught during the train crash, while the camera wasstill rolling film. Something crawls up out the wreckage, and dashes out of the frame. The boys decide to delve into the mystery themselves, and the adventure begins.     The performances in this film are amazing, especially from newcomer Joel Courtney, Riley Griffiths, and Elle Fanning. Each delivers an incredibly genuine performance, and I was blown away by the raw energy displayed on screen. The direction is perfect, with splashes of J.J. Abrams idol, Spielberg, splashed about the screen in nearly every frame. The musical score is magical. The mystery is involving. It all makes for an excellent time at the theatre, and will make you long for the days when summer blockbusters had a soul. With strong messages of hope and forgiveness, it is also one of the most touching films to come out in a while.     Super 8 is rated PG-13, and is 112 minutes.

0739375970|5.0|This is an excellent book (audio) that meets all the standards: unpredictability (like life), good people doing stupid things, good people doing good things and so on. Martin's well woven tapestry covers a land that is fascinating to visit but I wouldn't want to live there. Oh no! The best part of this series is being able to visit such a world; the worst part is now it will be years before we can get back in. For those people who are disappointed I can offer no solace except the knowledge that there is always another book in the offing. For folks like me, it is indeed a great ride. Characters you love to hate end up being sympathetic and you actually root for certain people to succeed while only a few hundred pages before you'd like to see them burned--and you'd gladly toss the torches yourself. The book does move the plot lines along in a way that is almost medieval in pace and yet the point of view chapters help to keep the world spinning and show the characters as fresh and as complex as they appear to be, and so they are.<br /><br />Jon Snow, Ariya, Dani, Tyrion are characters for the ages.<br /><br />My major concern with the series is a familiar one. When the family moves to the second house the plot just takes this huge leap from demonic possession/haunting to astral-projection and the fun-house horror of \\"The Further\\".  I actually would have been on board with the plot leap and the terrible pacing if the effects hadn't been so utterly absurd.      When Josh goes into \\"The Further\\" the movie quickly goes from a decent horror movie to a campy romp at the local fair's house of horrors.  Even low-budget movies should have better costume design than this, I've seen scarier Halloween costumes than anything that was presented in \\"The Further\\"!  I'm usually kind of a chicken when it comes to horror movies, but the second half of this movie was just so ridiculous I was too distracted to be scared.  Everything about this movie was kind of reminiscent of a really bad, really cheesy B horror movie from the 1950s, to the point where I started to think that maybe that was what the filmmakers were going for.    Other things I didn't like were the plot twist (very predictable from fairly early on) and the film's music score.  The music didn't really add suspense at all, it was just jarring and kind of kept me from getting too scared.  Overall, I'd say the preview for this movie was much better than the movie itself and I don't understand why its been so well-received.

I prefer a vegetarian diet, but eat some meat, so it has been hard to get in substitutes.  I use seitan products, quinoa and amaranth (plant products that are complete proteins) as well as soy, chicken, and a bit of beef.  But I am losing after being at a plateau for more than a year. 0316069884|4.0|This is among one of my favorite books in defense of making conscious food choices. Having been born and raised into a vegetarian family, I initially embraced vegetarianism out of necessity and later out of habit.  As such, I've never really wanted to make a statement about vegetarianism or make it seem like I was upholding some greater ideal because I've always known that many of the more complex emotional aspects of 'giving up meat' or 'going vegetarian' were not my reality. Instead, I've fielded the various questions about my dietary habits by referencing my family history and 'inherited' food culture.  In later years, I've come to understand and experience the environmental, societal and health benefits of being vegetarian, and I am deeply appreciative of this priceless legacy that my parents have left me.    As my husband and I consider having children ourselves, I wonder whether food choice will be as simple for our future kids as it was for me, and I question whether they will accept our family food choices as their own. What I like about this book is that Foer intricately weaves a story about his own challenges with food choice as well as the catalyst that the birth of his first child had on the approach he and his wife have now taken in raising their kids. While no person or book can provide 'the answer' to these life questions, I appreciated the way Foer writes about the topic in a more comprehensive and personal way than I've seen from other authors. I recommend it to anyone looking to broaden his or her perspective on food and food choice.

Getting past the parts I didn't care for I could never hate Mockingjay. Collins made me so emotionally attached to Katniss that any ending of the series would have pleased me. I think the book was well written and examined human relationships, which is when the series is at it's finest. All in all, it wasn't a bad way to spend a summer day.

B002ZG99QS|3.0|To be perfectly honest I didn't expect to like TRON: Legacy, but as I sat watching it unfold before my eyes, I realized that something was happening that rarely happens to me.  I was seeing something I had never seen before.  The world of TRON: Legacy, although it resembles vaguely the world of the first film, is a much darker, moodier, and more beautiful world.  The story is familiar, but I found myself totally immersed in it, watching with delight the entirely original realm of the digital world.  In short: I loved TRON: Legacy.     The film begins in 1989, about seven years after the end of the first film with a digitally de-aged Jeff Bridges reprising his role as Kevin Flynn, a computer programmer and now head of a giant computer company called Encom, telling his son Sam about his adventures in the digital world and how he invented the video game \\"TRON\\".  Sam listens in amazement to what his dad has to say, and Flynn even promises to take him to the \\"Grid\\" one day.  Then suddenly, Kevin disappears, leaving his son an orphan and his company in ruins.  Twenty-one years later, Sam (Garrett Hedlund) finds the portal to the digital world his father created, to find not only his father, but also the system in ruins.  All of this takes about twenty minutes of screen time, which seems to me, in light of the subject matter, to be a bit of a long intro.  This film takes itself a little more seriously than the original, and as a result, can get away with a lot more generic story plots.  But the faults in the screenplay are hardly noticeable since we are so immersed in the visuals.  Seriously, this is one good lookin' film.  It is dark and atmospheric, and the CGI is used not just to dazzle us, but really as a kind of story devise, something rare in modern Hollywood films.  To all of the fans of the original TRON, take heart, because all of the iconic images from that film have been either transferred over to or improved upon in this one.  One of the best action scenes in the movie is a light-cycle battle much like the chase scene from film one, but instead of taking place on just one, two-dimensional coordinate plane, it now takes place on a multi-leveled grid which allows for some of the most fascinating and exciting shots of this past year.    Honestly, it's one of the best visual production designs in recent years.  The picture is so dark and cold looking, it's tranquil and peaceful and quiet despite the war going on around.  Where the first movie looked bizarre, electric, and colorful, this movie is the exact opposite.  As I said earlier, I've never seen anything like it.  I'll forgive the plot inaccuracies and contrivances just because of the visual style of the film.  It's really quite stunning, like something you might dream of.  Not anything like the first film.  There's something to be said for pure wonder and spectacle in a film, and I was bedazzled by TRON: Legacy.    I think my only serious problem with TRON: Legacy was its length.  At two hours and five minutes, it seemed way too long for this kind of film.  I think cutting about a half of an hour would have made it a much more acceptable running time.  By the time the credits rolled, despite my involvement in the motion picture, I found myself jumping out of my seat to get going.  It's way too long, a rather big problem in an otherwise wonderful film.  It's no masterpiece, but it's a whole heck of a lot better than TRON and for that matter, better than most of the recently released Disney sequels.  I hope that other such visually striking films will be married to a better screenplay, and then we'd have a rare sci-fi masterpiece.  I was suspicious of the ending, which seemed to leave room for TRON 3, a film I would greatly discourage.  A concept like that of the TRON films is a complex and interesting one that could probably be open to a lot of real philosophical debate.  If perhaps the film had been a little more understandable, and a little more thought provoking, it would have gone beyond a good sci-fi picture and could have been, well, great.         -Cole Webb Harter    read the full review at: [...]
159514188X|4.0|I started this book at 1 am Friday night and read until I couldn't keep my eyes open. As soon as I woke up Saturday I began reading it again and quickly finished. I was captivated by this book. The basic plot is this: Clay finds that he has been given seven cassette tapes that he must listen to. These tapes are narrated by Hannah, a girl he knows from school. When he's done with the tapes he has to pass them on to the next person on the list. I don't think it's a spoiler to tell you that Hannah recently killed herself and on these tapes are the thirteen reasons why she did it. What happens next is a morality story about treating people nicely and being aware that even the smallest actions have consequences. I thought this book would become to preachy about loving your neighbor, being nice to everyone, blah blah blah. However, I was pleasantly surprised that it was not. Jay Asher simply presents the readers with the facts and then lets them draw their own conclusions. I became emotionally invested in Hannah and hoped that in some surprise ending she didn't actually commit suicide.   This book is beautifully written with the view points of both Hannah and Clay alternating simultaneously. I read this over a week ago and I still can't get Hannah out of my head

0316067938|2.0|** spoiler alert ** Okay, I admit it it. I was a twihard. I read the first three books and then eagerly anticipated the release of the final installment of the series. I went to the bookstore at eleven p.m. on release night and waited it out for an hour with throngs of teenage girls. After I went home and recovered from all the squealing I began to read the series. Unfortunately, I was instantly disappointed. The beauty of the series was the build up of sexual tension between Bella, Jacob and Edward. (Not all three at the same time, although that might be interesting). There was some action in the first three books but for me the central conflict was always, who will she choose? The fourth book completely took this element out and left the final book feeling vacant and like a shell of it's more compassionate predecessors.   When Bella chooses Edward and they are married I felt like it all happened to quickly. What happened to Bella's confusion over Jacob? Breaking Dawn starts like a horse race and never lets up. Bella and Edward are married. Then she gets pregnant? How is this even possible? Edward is dead, shouldn't all of his sperm have followed suit and died when he became a member of the no pulse club? Okay, okay even if I believe that a vampire can impregnate a human (and on the first try too!) is it really necessary for Bella and Edward to have a child? Can't they be married awhile? Experience the slump after the honeymoon period? She can get fat and they can fight over the remote? Apparently not. As soon as little Renesmee (I'll just let that one go) is born Bella has to quickly be turned into a vampire because she would be unable to survive the half vampire child's birth if she were human. Right. Perhaps, they should have thought about poor delicate Bella pushing out a vampire child before they had sex. I'm just saying. Since, they were both going to be vampires anyway then this whole mess could have been avoided. But no, because then we wouldn't have a plot. The rest of the plot is fuzzy to me. Dainty Bella becomes dainty vampire Bella and Jacob uses Renesmee as the rebound girl after her mom broke his heart. Well to be fair, Renesmee is a newborn and will not techinically become the rebound girl until she is old enough to give consent. But, he imprinted on her so her consent is not really important. (Don't even get me started on that. The lack of a feminist hero in this series is incredibly sad).   I feel like Stephenie Meyer felt the pressure of quickly writing the final novel to her series, which had become wildly popular overnight. Unfortunately I think she dropped the ball. The problem with writing a novel quickly is that the character development that was so crucial to the other three books is lost. I loved the first three books but I could not get into this last one.

1416955070|3.0|I'm not entirely sure what to say about City of Bones. The plot is not exactly what one would call original and I found myself being taken out of the novel because of the familiarity. There were some points where exact lines were word for word plucked from something else. Now I'm not saying she plagiarized it's just the phrases she chose to use are so common it felt at times like I had already read this. Not just the phrases are familiar either. I read somewhere that Cassandra Clare was a popular Harry Potter fan fiction writer before hitting it \\"big\\" with her Mortal Instruments Series and that made sense. The villain reminded me of Lord Voldemort so much so that when I was reading his dialogue I could hear Ralph Fiennes saying it in his creepy Voldemort voice. I don't blame Clare for using Voldemort as the basis for her villain, Valentine, because I too am a fan. However, I felt like I already read this novel. There are also bits of Twilight and Star Wars that seem to seep into the narrative.   Despite my general dislike of the novel and my ability to get every \\"secret\\" or plot point way before the protagonist I didn't hate City of Bones. I know I should, the creepy ending alone is enough to make me throw my book at the wall, but I can't. The actual demon hunting and slaying is fun and the sheer amount of mystical creatures was enough for me to keep reading. (Well that and the creepy \\"plot twist\\" at the end. I kept thinking, Oh Gross! This can't be true. But alas...) Clare created a beautiful landscape and filled it with potentially interesting characters. Having just finished this a few hours ago I'm still unsure whether or not I would recommend it to someone. It's a fun summer read but also a bit derivative of other, better works. I must admit that I do plan to read the next book in the trilogy out of pure curiosity. Hopefully, it succeeds my expectation

B004XQO90O|4.0|Not since Minority Report has there been a really good time suspension futuristic-like thriller that has really captivated me and held my attention.  I didn't expect that at all from Source Code, but it exceeded at just that.<br /><br />Jake plays a helicopter pilot named Colter who has been \\"killed\\" in combat and should be dead, but when his brain still shows signs of activity he's entered into a test program called Source Code.  It claims that when someone dies, their brain records the last eight minutes of their life.  The military created Source Code to insert someone else into that eight minute recording in disguise as the dead person in order to combat terrorists or learn more information about who committed the crime. Colter is being sent onto a passenger train bound for Chicago, disguised as a teacher who was on that train, in order to find out who planted a bomb on it. The bomber is claiming to blow up Chicago later that day, as the train has already exploded that morning and Colter is \\"going back in time\\" in sort of a role playing scenario to figure out who did it.<br /><br />The conflict here is that Colter doesn't know how all of this is possible.  He has no knowledge of his real life events or of the events that have already taken place with the train.  He thinks he's in some sort of training simulation.  As details are unveiled to both him and the viewer, the plot really gets going and both will begin to contemplate what is real and what is imaginary.  And Colter begins to wonder if his actions in Source Code can or cannot really affect what has already happened.<br /><br />It's deeper than just time travel and much more intense that just some military action thriller.  Jake does a good job in this one and his acting seemed very real and believable.  I didn't remember much about the movie when it was first being advertised, but it looked good enough to rent and I'm glad I did.  I was well pleased overall and definitely taken by surprise.  Great film!  You may even have to watch it a second time to catch all the details that really lay out the plot, but definitely be prepared to be entertained!tch it a second time to catch all the details that really lay out the plot, but definitely be prepared to be entertained!

0385341679|4.0|I very much enjoyed spending time in Moning's world throughout this series. This final book tied up most of the loose ends nicely, in a mostly satisfying way. I look forward to reading any spinoff series she's planning.<br /><br />I think where Moning shines most is in her characterization and world-building. Each character had very distinct voice and I enjoyed the consistency from one book to the next. I loved Dublin (warts and all), and felt Moning was able to immerse me into the city (and other worlds) very realistically. I also love her gift of dialogue and banter - especially between Mac and Barrons. It made them so real to me.<br /><br />All that said, I think this series would have shined even more if it was written a little more tightly, maybe into three books instead of five. There seemed to be a lot of repetition. Mac seemed to think back to when she first came to Dublin and compare herself to her present life multiple times in each book. While I understand why she needed the reflection (and her changing is a major component of the storyline), I felt that it became redundant.<br /><br />Starting with the third book, Mac also seemed to start making the same mistakes over and over again (with her relationship with Barrons and with her trying to figure out who she really was and how to defeat the book, etc.), and spinning around in place instead of growing as fast as she should have. I think if the author would have cut out some of the \\"spinning\\", and let some of the questions be answered earlier, or just tightened up the story to a trilogy, it would have been stronger overall. That said, it was well worth the time I spent on it, and feel it deserves four stars (this final book, and the series overall).

B00006DEF9|5.0|\\"Singin' in the Rain\\" is one of the best movie musicals, as well as one of the best movies about the movies, ever made.  Set at the dawn of the talking picture era, the film concerns silent film stars, Don Lockwood (Gene Kelly) and Lina Lamont (Jean Hagen), a tremendously popular romantic duo, who attempt the difficult (and for many, impossible) transition from silent pictures to the talkies.    The acting honors here go to Hagen, who gives one of the funniest performances in movie history, playing a leading lady with a voice like fingernails on a chalkboard.  As Lockwood's best friend, Cosmo Brown (Donald O'Connor), says, she  is a triple threat:   \\"She can't act, she can't sing, she can't dance.\\"     Kelly was never better.  O'Connor and Debbie Reynolds, as Lockwood's love interest give fine performances as well.  The entire cast, even down to the minor characters, is superb.    Directors Kelly and Stanley Donen work movie magic.  The songs by Arthur Freed and Nacio Herb Brown are perfectly integrated into a witty script by Adolph Green and Betty Comden.  There are numerous memorable musical numbers, the best being Kelly's rendition of the title song, sung as he dances down a rain-soaked Hollywood street.    This film is a must for any fan of musicals, or movies period!

0553801473|2.0|I'm new to the series. I came to it via the HBO show, devoured all the books back to back in the past 6 weeks, and loved them - even AFFC, which puts me in the minority in terms of ASOIAF readership. So it really pains me to say that I found this book to be an excruciating read.<br /><br />If storytelling is the art of poetically crafting the essentials, then this book has failed miserably; repetitive, indulgent, meandering, full of one dimensional side characters (everyone not from Westeros), poorly drawn environments (everywhere east of Westeros) and monotonously developing main characters. Not to mention a preponderance of coincidental events that would stretch the credulity of a 10 year old... even for a fantasy series.<br /><br />Logan Pearsall Smith said \\"What I like in a good author is not what he says, but what he whispers.\\" Well, GRRM says far too much in this book and hardly ever whispers. ADWD is at least 300 pages too long for the story it's telling, and yet, amazingly, it still manages to end in a way that leaves the reader frustrated rather than satisfied, starved rather than nourished. It's a case of too many words for too little plot development.<br />For dredging through page upon ponderous page of unnecessary and mind-numbing fluff you are rewarded with not a single resolution to the myriad of old, and some new, open threads in this series.<br /><br />Writing this book was hard work for GRRM, and it shows.

0066620996|3.0|After hearing about it in the pop psychology book [[ASIN:0307459667 The Invisible Gorilla]], I decided to read something I had seen so much about a few years ago: Good to Great. While the author of Great felt as if they his team had achieved something great in their study--real replicable science--the assessment in Gorilla was that Jim Collins didn't use science at all. Collins took companies that were great and tried to find what the common denominator was, then contrasted them with similar companies that did not become great. Science would be take a random selection of companies, put half of them on the Good to Great recipe and the others the not-so-great recipe and see the results.<br /><br />Of course, that would be nearly impossible to do in the business world. No one would want to participate in a study in which they were the control group which would lead to failure supposedly. So, unfortunately, this isn't science.<br /><br />All you need to do for proof of that is to look at one of the Great companies he talks about: Fannie Mae. Really? Fannie Mae a great company? Somehow, I just can't put a government-sponsored-enterprise free from real competition which also invented some of the risky investment vehicles which caused the economic collapse of 2008 in the great category. Of course, its greatness could have evaporated in the short time from the revision of this book (2005) to the housing market implosion in which Fannie was such a horrific victim of its own corrupt financial devices that Collins praised (it required and still requires billions of taxpayer money to stave off catastrophic bankruptcy).<br /><br />Okay, so if you excuse the author and his team for blowing it on Fannie Mae and you can get past the cheesy `90s catchphrases like \\"level 5 leader\\" \\"Hedgehog Concept\\" and the most irritating, \\"wash your cottage cheese,\\" you will enjoy this book. I do like the idea of following your passion and looking at the facts. Then again, it may bother you that Collins makes one final point at the end of the book that makes absolutely no sense: it doesn't matter what core values your company has just as long as you have values and stick to it. That's what will make yours a great company says Collins. Well, I guess having the wrong kind of values worked for Fannie Mae . . . at least for a few years.int at the end of the book that makes absolutely no sense: it doesn't matter what core values your company has just as long as you have values and stick to it. That's what will make yours a great company says Collins. Well, I guess having the wrong kind of values worked for Fannie Mae . . . at least for a few years.

B003ELOQCK|3.0|I am an avid U2 fan, having loved their tunes after falling in love with Mysterious Ways as an 8 or 9 year old back in 1991. My first album was Zooropa, and I was the only person in my circle-of-friends who actually liked (and still likes!) Pop. I lost touch of them after I couldn't score tix for the Elevation Tour, and found them after buying their Atomic Bomb album with a gift card given me as a Christmas gift from a former boss. I saw them on the Vertigo Tour in Atlanta with my best friend and his dad, about 10-feet from the b-side ramp. Edge playing his Until the End of the World solo and the band ending the night with Bad were my two main highlights.    Fast forward a few years, and to No Line On the Horizon. Personally, I think it is their best, most realised album since Achtung Baby (my personal favorite). So, when my mom called me to say that she scored 4 tix for us to see the opening North American show in Chicago---stating, \\"Who's the most kickass mom in the world!!!\\"---I was stoked beyond belief. And, rightfully so. In a word, the show was epic. Almost overwhelmingly so (they spontaneously ended the main set with Bad, for crying out loud!).    So here we are at this dvd, which is the closest I have to a memento from my Chicago show. Minus the absence of Bad, I think the Rose Bowl setlist is overall better.  (The band later adding Hold Me Thrill Me Kiss Me Kill Me and swapping I Will Follow and New Years Day depending on the night is even better!).  On this dvd, the band performs with uncanny energy, and Bono's is more consistently strong throughout than on most of their recent dvds.     So, what are my two quibbles? The first has been voiced by many below: editing Breath out of its opening slot. It may not be the best opener, but the martial drums starting things off sent such intense shivers down my spine in Chicago that it is an utter shame that Get On Your Boots has been relegated as the opener. Second, the audience volume is turned WAYYYY too low formuch of this recording. At Chicago, the audience singing along was audible for the majority of the show, particularly for Still Haven't Found, Bad, Sunday Bloody Sunday, Pride and With Or Without You (the same can be said for Atlanta on the Vertigo Tour). Even when the audience is turned up, it sounds too weak. Compare the video of Breath on the bonus disc to the main dvd. Compare the audience in the ZOOTV dvd, particularly when Bono prowls the ramp during Until the End of the World.      Overall, this dvd is epic, and despite my beefs, I recommend it! 3.5 stars!

B003UESJH4|5.0|This is an excellent film that explores the ability to overcome adversity and the power of relationships in providing the support needed to overcome adversity. Colin Firth plays Prince Albert, the Duke of York, who later becomes George VI. Helena Bonham-Carter plays his wife Elizabeth. Early in the film we see that the loving relationship between Elizabeth and her husband, Bertie, as he is called by family members, is in stark contrast to the chilly formal relationship that Bertie has to his father King George V and his mother, Queen Mary. Michael Gambon plays King George V, a not unsympathetic figure, but certainly completely in the dark in understanding the stammer with which Bertie struggles. It is Elizabeth, Duchess of York, who pursues some efforts to help her husband it is she who makes the first contacts with Lionel Logue, an Australian, who came to London after World War I. Gradually a relationship is built between Lionel and Bertie on which the speech therapy can progress. But there is an underlying reason why this story is of such importance. England faced a great challenge with the growth of Nazi Germany and the future was uncertain. In addition, after the death of George V, Bertie's older brother Edward became king. King Edward VIII was not mentally strong or emotionally mature enough to serve as king and he abdicates the throne to marry an American woman who had been twice divorced. Guy Pearce is excellent as Edward VIII, a charming and sophisticated man with limited intelligence and strength of character.  Thus Bertie and Elizabeth are thrown into roles they never expected to inherit and Bertie, as George VI, must be the voice of authority and reassurance as England enters a tense and unsure time in relationship to Nazi Germany. This is the historic background on which the film is based, but the film actually spends the majority of time exploring the interactions between Bertie and Lionel as Lionel helps Bertie explore the emotional underpinnings of his stammer and develop the skills to overcome the disability. Elizabeth finds Lionel and begins to believe in his services but the relationship with Bertie has several starts and stops.  Lionel comes to understand that Bertie has the moral character and determination to lead England should a war arise with Germany and Bertie comes to judge Lionel by the services he offers and the devotion he has to Bertie rather than by his credentials. The room in which Bertie and Lionel work is certainly worth mentioning since it is a large room with skylights and about 20 layers of wallpaper scraps clinging to the walls forming a fascinating collage that serves as the background of much of the human interaction in the film.  Lionel is extremely protective of the process he undertakes with Bertie and even his wife, played by Jennifer Ehle, does not know the true identity of this client. All the actors were superb and Colin Firth is excellent as George VI but Geoffrey Rush was spectacular as Lionel. The film is excellent and its core message of teamwork and trusting relationships in overcoming adversity rings true.

1451629184|4.0|This is not a heavily edited masterpiece. It isn't even a usual memoir by any means. So one can't review based on whether the storytelling is \\"good\\" or not -- it isn't what the author meant to convey. You have to let the contents sit and be felt. Let's be honest, some parts of the book were boring and repetitive, but that's exactly how she felt her life in captivity to be, and how else could the depth of that be told?    This is a distressing book to read. The graphic contents and \\"shock\\" are early on and brief, but it is always in the back of your mind. The most distressing parts come later though, when time drags itself out, hope fades, and you realize her prison is not physical, but psychological. B0054U53WG|5.0|In the late 90's a young Larry Page, enrolled at Stanford in Computer Science, needed a subject for his Phd dissertation. His was a razor sharp engineering mind, but he was in need of something big, something worthy of his geek brain. They say technology lies on the edge of complexity, and thus, in those days, the most complex thing was the Internet, just a few years from launching into the mainstream. The web was growing at an amazing rate, truly a worth challenge for Page. That Stanford project became Google (not Googol), and today, the web is sprawling more than it ever has, making a Search engine, on the face of it, worth more than it ever was. Amidst infinite complexity, Google's algorithm has incredible value precisely because the world, and the web, is incredibly complex.<br /><br />The story of Google turns out to be a nice little summary of the last 15 or so years of Computing, picking up right about the time our last gen Silicon Valley Royals (those being Steve Jobs and Bill Gates) buried the hatchet (that story, by the way, is depicted nicely in the great \\"Pirates of Silicon Valley\\" TV Movie by Noah Wyle and Anthony Michael Hall, respectively).<br /><br />So why read a book about Google anyway? Well the truth is, most people won't. Most people will find this stuff incredibly dry. Everyone wants a Google business card, but few of us actually want to actually work at Google and stay up for 14 hours discussing search algorithms, Gmail Spambots and Google Streetview. Engineers, however, love this stuff. The simple act of saying, \\"This is hard, it's never been done before, it's probably impossible\\" is the equivalent of telling Schwarzenegger in the late 70's that he couldn't pick up a huge boulder. He's going to pick that rock up or die trying.<br /><br />The other thing Engineers like is money. It turns out that if you go back to Apple in the 80's, Microsoft in the 90's, and Google in the 2000's (and now Facebook in the 2010's), Engineers go wherever the IPO tells them to go. And thus we find ourselves in an interesting position: Google has lost some of its smartest people, and Facebook is the coolest kid on the block. Despite all the bad press, Mark Zuckerberg (who famously had more Facebook plaintiffs than Friends) is the most popular kid on Google Plus (Google's Facebook wannabe).<br /><br />But before we get into that, let's take a step back and try to understand what really drives this company: Google was never about making money. In fact, the founders taunted the business guys, mostly because they weren't smart enough to be Engineers. To be an MBA with no Engineering experience at Google is to be, in a way, a second class citizen. And yet Google gets richer and richer, almost as if to say, \\"We can do this stuff without even trying. What do we need you for?\\"<br /><br />So how does Google make money? By saving the logs of everything everybody on the Internet searches for, they can track incredibly detailed patterns of behaviour (like the way our brains have muscle memory and habits). If Google understands what you want, maybe Google can anticipate what you're looking for. And thus, perhaps they could actually give you an ad that you didn't hate. This is the point. You're not supposed to hate Google Ads. You're supposed to like them. And for that, Advertisers pay big money. Ideally, it's a win-win. If an advertiser starts talking to you about something you want, they're not annoying; they're actually useful.<br /><br />Here's where it gets really interesting: you may have heard that Google's mission is to organize the world's information. As such, it's inextricably tied to the growth of the Web. And thus, Google will do anything that promotes Web usage. This is why almost all Google services are free.<br /><br />Who could argue with this great business model? You take something that people are looking for, and give it to them for free. They never pay anything (like TV commercials), and we get big businesses to foot the bill. But Google does have its critics, namely Privacy advocates. Google often responds to criticism by calling upon the Invisible hand of the market: \\"If we do something wrong, people will tell us, and they'll stop using our stuff, and thus, the product will fail.\\" It's the kind of undeniable and irrefutable logic that almost suggests the Governments step away from all consumer protection. There's just one problem: a similar defence could be used for Drug Dealers. After all, the addicts keep coming back, they obviously like the product right? (What's the emoticon for sarcasm again?)<br /><br />And what's Google's drug in this analogy? Free (as in Beer). By getting the users hooked on free, they can pull in the advertisers. And it turns out, as long as you have lots of white space (Google's most preferred design language. Ahem.) you can put ads there. And if you suggest Google is exploiting people, they will respond that they are merely anticipating what their users are looking for and suggesting solutions. We users should be so lucky.<br /><br />Don't think of Google as a Search Engine, or a business; think of Google as a Brain. And where is that brain? Strewn around the world in Google's top secret Data Centres of course, where it holds indexes of everything on the Web, with its own fibers engineered to bring you the fastest results it possibly can. Like a man made Cerebral cortex connected to the worlds most efficient and genetically perfect spinal cord. Zero Downtime, Unlimited Memory and Super-Speed.<br /><br />You see, human brains are great, but they have this little problem of wearing down and expiring every 80 or so years.<br /><br />So if you're going to build a mechianical brain that can live forever, first you have to teach it stuff (Indexing the world's Information), and you have to give it a great memory (aforementioned Data Centers). As the brain becomes more intelligent, soon you'll want it to learn to speak (Google Translate) and develop feelings and social skills, which brings us back to Google+, Google's \\"Facebook-killer\\".<br /><br />So Social turns out to be the next phase in building a brain. Ironically, such technology only helps Google anticipate the users' wants and needs, feeding them better ads. Your friends know you.. they know what you like. That's why Apple integrated something called Ping into iTunes.. they figured your friends knew what kind of music you like better than a computer algorithm (previously known as iTunes Genius).<br /><br />And Mark Zuckerberg figures your friends who actually know you know what kind of cola you drink, what kind of shoes you like, better than some computer. Your friends have actual brains. They're humans. As Business Guru Tom Peters famously said, the soft stuff is the hard stuff.<br /><br />The next level of search will come full circle, riding on the back of actual humans who know you. After all the fiber-optic cables have been laid and multi-million dollar data centres have been built, Zuckerberg, Brin and Page are the guys at the party, asking your friends what you want for your birthday, then handing you a brightly coloured package. As you tear off the wrapping paper, you can't believe it: \\"Wow! This is perfect! How did you know I was looking for a new Tennis Racquet? I love it!\\"<br /><br />I guess some questions are better left unanswered.  ;)<br /><br />More reviews like this at 21tigery advocates. Google often responds to criticism by calling upon the Invisible hand of the market: \\"If we do something wrong, people will tell us, and they'll stop using our stuff, and thus, the product will fail.\\" It's the kind of undeniable and irrefutable logic that almost suggests the Governments step away from all consumer protection. There's just one problem: a similar defence could be used for Drug Dealers. After all, the addicts keep coming back, they obviously like the product right? (What's the emoticon for sarcasm again?)    And what's Google's drug in this analogy? Free (as in Beer). By getting the users hooked on free, they can pull in the advertisers. And it turns out, as long as you have lots of white space (Google's most preferred design language. Ahem.) you can put ads there. And if you suggest Google is exploiting people, they will respond that they are merely anticipating what their users are looking for and suggesting solutions. We users should be so lucky.     Don't think of Google as a Search Engine, or a business; think of Google as a Brain. And where is that brain? Strewn around the world in Google's top secret Data Centres of course, where it holds indexes of everything on the Web, with its own fibers engineered to bring you the fastest results it possibly can. Like a man made Cerebral cortex connected to the worlds most efficient and genetically perfect spinal cord. Zero Downtime, Unlimited Memory and Super-Speed.    You see, human brains are great, but they have this little problem of wearing down and expiring every 80 or so years.    So if you're going to build a mechianical brain that can live forever, first you have to teach it stuff (Indexing the world's Information), and you have to give it a great memory (aforementioned Data Centers). As the brain becomes more intelligent, soon you'll want it to learn to speak (Google Translate) and develop feelings and social skills, which brings us back to Google+, Google's \\"Facebook-killer\\".    SoSocial turns out to be the next phase in building a brain. Ironically, such technology only helps Google anticipate the users' wants and needs, feeding them better ads. Your friends know you.. they know what you like. That's why Apple integrated something called Ping into iTunes.. they figured your friends knew what kind of music you like better than a computer algorithm (previously known as iTunes Genius).    And Mark Zuckerberg figures your friends who actually know you know what kind of cola you drink, what kind of shoes you like, better than some computer. Your friends have actual brains. They're humans. As Business Guru Tom Peters famously said, the soft stuff is the hard stuff.    The next level of search will come full circle, riding on the back of actual humans who know you. After all the fiber-optic cables have been laid and multi-million dollar data centres have been built, Zuckerberg, Brin and Page are the guys at the party, asking your friends what you want for your birthday, then handing you a brightly coloured package. As you tear off the wrapping paper, you can't believe it: \\"Wow! This is perfect! How did you know I was looking for a new Tennis Racquet? I love it!\\"    I guess some questions are better left unanswered.  ;)    More reviews like this at 21tiger

This movie features Lightning McQueen (Owen Wilson), but more of the focus seems to be around Mator (Larry The Cable Guy) who returns as a bumbling goof and gets himself mixed up in some spy business. B004Q84Z0S|5.0|Ariodante ranks with Juliuo Cesare, Alcina, and Tamerlano as one of the four greatest of Handel's  operatic output. My first introduction to this masterpiece was years ago on lp's with Janet Baker in the title role under Raymond Leppard and, as is the case with many recordings from one's past, this one still holds much special meaning for me and I treasure her in this role.<br /><br />Later, however, and lucky for Handel fans, a series of great(er) recordings have come along, not least of which have seen Lorraine Hunt-Lieberson and Anne Sophie von Otter tackle the work. This latter, under Minkowski, has long been my favorite recording as I am sure it has for many others.<br /><br />A few years back I happily discovered Alan Curtis and his great work with the operas of Handel and Vivaldi. My esteem for him and his efforts has steadily risen and I now consider him the greatest proponent of these two giants' operas, and I have come to look forward to each new recording from him.<br /><br />This Ariodante, with Joyce DiDonato in the title role, is simply stunning and seems to be completely balanced, with everything in the right place vocally and instrumentally. The sound here is just wonderful, and to my ears completely idiomatic to this composer and his time, with Il Complesso Barocco again delivering a fabulous performance. I would place Curtis' efforts firmly alongside Minkowski's for direction of this work.<br /><br />As much as I like the previous singers of the role, DiDonato clearly rises above them all. She has mastered Handel's idiomatic style completely and seems \\"born\\" into this role. Her vocal delivery here is so beautiful as to be clearly the best we have heard, and to my ear impeccable. Her coloring of each aria quite simply opens doors into Handelian interpretation. Simply put, she is unmatched by any of the previous singers. Her execution of Handel's text throughout is marvelous, every utterance just seems tempered and delivered to perfection, breathing greater life into this role than we have seen before. Her trills will knock you back in your seat and her \\"Dopo note\\" is stunning. The \\"Scherza infida\\" is shaded and delivered more darkly by her here and it is simply fantastic!<br /><br />Karen Gauvin as Genevra is quite commendable, able to wring out all our sympathy, and I doubt anyone would have any disappointment with her interpretation or abilities. Marie-Nicole Lemiux sweeps everyone before her in her dark portrail of Polinesso. She, also, just seems born for her role here. Lurcanio, sung here by Topi Lehtipuu, is totally commendable and certainly on par with, perhaps better, than previous singers on other recordings.<br /><br />All in all, this new Ariodante clearly is a first choice for anyone coming to this opera for the first time, and it is definitely a \\"Must-Have\\" for seasoned Handel fans. I would expect that later this year when the Awards Season arrives, this will be a clear winner for best Opera Recording of the Year!<br /><br />You're gonna love this recording!<br /><br />****And, better yet, look at the price! How can you resist that, Handel Fans?****n we have seen before. Her trills will knock you back in your seat and her \\"Dopo note\\" is stunning. The \\"Scherza infida\\" is shaded and delivered more darkly by her here and it is simply fantastic!    Karen Gauvin as Genevra is quite commendable, able to wring out all our sympathy, and I doubt anyone would have any disappointment with her interpretation or abilities. Marie-Nicole Lemiux sweeps everyone before her in her dark portrail of Polinesso. She, also, just seems born for her role here. Lurcanio, sung here by Topi Lehtipuu, is totally commendable and certainly on par with, perhaps better, than previous singers on other recordings.    All in all, this new Ariodante clearly is a first choice for anyone coming to this opera for the first time, and it is definitely a \\"Must-Have\\" for seasoned Handel fans. I would expect that later this year when the Awards Season arrives, this will be a clear winner for best Opera Recording of the Year!    You're gonna love this recording!    ****And, better yet, look at the price! How can you resist that, Handel Fans?****

B0018AK9RA|5.0|I have been a Priest fan for decades and when I heard about this concept album, I was skeptical but decided to go for it.  I'll be honest; when I first heard it, I was like \\"WTF?\\"  After hearing such songs like \\"Pestilence and Plague,\\" I was quite ready to shelve this thing and call it a day.  Then, while doing my Greek homework (yeah, I'm a dichotomy...listening to a heavy metal story sung by a gay man about an occultist mystic while doing Christian Seminary studies); the beauty of this work began to shine through.  It is a sad journey about a tormented man with visions of apocalyptic destruction, the loss of his family, and being ostracized by his community.  You can feel Nostradamus' questioning of God and his crazy life while trying to deal with his obvious issues...something of which so many of us can relate.<br /><br />The guitars range from biting-edge to melodious darkness and the song that I hated most; \\"Pestilence and Plague,\\" transitioned from my least favorite to the top four most played songs on this cd.  I never cared for opera, but Halfords ability to tell a story not only with lyrics, but with such operatic vocal inflection, is nothing less than amazing.  Also, the, song \\"Future of Mankind,\\" reflects so much vocal emotion that one must ask if this is Rob Helford's question instead of the title character--a masterpiece of singing.<br /><br />I have Judas Priest's \\"Angel of Retribution,\\" of which I am quite fond.  But after one listening of that work, I have to call it quits for a while (especially the last minute of Lochness--makes me want to pull what hair I have left out of my skull).  Nostradamus, on the other hand; is a flowing \\"metallurgy\\" of meaningful movements from sweet silent reflection to full-on rage!  I will enter the realm of blasphemy and say that Nostradamus ranks up there with Rush and Pink Floyd's ability to create lush stories designed for mind trips.  Great driving music and if you can try this alone on a road trip during a lightning storm, I promise you will be hooked.ise you will be hooked.

0307595862|4.0|Pushed by a brief but glowing sentence of praise from Michael Connelly, possibly the best of American mystery/thrillwriters, I succumbed to the lure of \\"The Snowman\\", by Jo Nesbo.<br /><br />Since the untimely demise of Scandinavian author Stieg Larsson, who set his thriller/killer trilogy OUTSIDE the standard approach of the police procedural, publishing houses, taken unawares by the incredible acclaim and book sales generated by Larsson's \\"The Girl\\" (with the Dragon Tattoo, etc.) in the English translation, have rushed to bring other Scandinavian authors to the American scene, with varying amounts of acclaim.<br /><br />Jo Nesbo, living and setting his novels in Oslo, Norway, briefly worked in journalism, but is an accomplished musician.  Nesbo published his first crime novel, featuring Detective Harry Hole, in 1997, some 8 years before Larsson's first novel went to press.  That successful novel, \\"The Bat Man\\" won two national awards for best crime novel in Norway.  Thus far, this novel and the second in the Harry Hole series, \\"The Cockroaches\\" have not been translated into English.  \\"The Snowman\\" is actually the 6th book in the series, and Nesbo followed up with \\"The Leopard\\", published this year.  As the series has progressed, Nesbo has won more and more world wide acclaim for his characterization of the flawed detective, his use of the visual to introduce some especially gruesome crime stories to his readers, and his exciting use of twists and turns that make it difficult for readers to predict his outcomes.<br /><br />Hole's an alcoholic, and I feel that Nesbo succeeds, quite apart from his skill with a police procedural, in his description of Hole's point of view on his disease, and also from his relationship with Rakel, the love of his life, who, at the start of \\"The Snowman\\" has found happiness with another.<br /><br />Nesbo's novel is about the disappearance of a number of women, under suspicious circumstances.  They start as missing persons cases, and it takes some time for the cases to be linked together.  The villain has left a cryptic message for detective Harry Hole, and the taunting voice of this note allows Hole to begin linking cases together, even as the timing of the disappearances of these wives/mothers begins to escalate.<br /><br />I may not have enjoyed this novel as much as others, because I have not read Nesbo's prior Harry Hole novels.  I found it moving too slowly in the first half of the book, and found the use of the visual symbol of the snowman to be a little distracting, and not as macabre as the author intended.<br /><br />By the middle of the novel however, having been led down a couple of false roads, the investigation, the willingness of the authorities to accept almost any plausible perpetrator (to quell fear of serial killing, almost unknown in Scandinavia) and the complication of Harry's relationship with his new partner all combined to make this a compelling read that kept me guessing right up to the end.  And I did, sit up all night, to finish the last half.<br /><br />It left me wanting more, and I will probably go back to the prior books to see if Nesbo can draw me in.  Satisfying, ironic in that Nesbo keeps his thread tied into the American political scene by using our presidential elections as a backdrop, well-crafted although plodding in the first half, \\"The Snowman\\" is well worth your time.o be linked together.  The villain has left a cryptic message for detective Harry Hole, and the taunting voice of this note allows Hole to begin linking cases together, even as the timing of the disappearances of these wives/mothers begins to escalate.     I may not have enjoyed this novel as much as others, because I have not read Nesbo's prior Harry Hole novels.  I found it moving too slowly in the first half of the book, and found the use of the visual symbol of the snowman to be a little distracting, and not as macabre as the author intended.    By the middle of the novel however, having been led down a couple of false roads, the investigation, the willingness of the authorities to accept almost any plausible perpetrator (to quell fear of serial killing, almost unknown in Scandinavia) and the complication of Harry's relationship with his new partner all combined to make this a compelling read that kept me guessing right up to the end.  And I did, sit up all night, to finish the last half.      It left me wanting more, and I will probably go back to the prior books to see if Nesbo can draw me in.  Satisfying, ironic in that Nesbo keeps his thread tied into the American political scene by using our presidential elections as a backdrop, well-crafted although plodding in the first half, \\"The Snowman\\" is well worth your time.

B000001ESP|5.0|This album is a classic from Rush.  It is their 8th studio album, released in 1981.  It is possibly their most popular and well known.  Due to this being the 80's, there is a bit more synth involved than on the early albums, but it is incorporated very well, in a bit of a timeless fashion.  It still has plenty of awesome guitar and bass work from Geddy Lee and Alex Lifeson, and Neil Peart has really hit his stride with insanely awesome drumming.  The album starts off with the radio staple \\"Tom Sawyer\\" showing much more synth than on their earlier albums, which I would recommend getting if you are only buying a few songs off this album.  The third song on the album, \\"YYZ\\", is a pretty awesome instrumental, also another song I would recommend buying if not buying the whole album.  YYZ is the airport code for Toronto Pearson International Airport, and the Morse Code for YYZ is played at the beginning of the song, and also is worked into the main riff.  The rest of the songs are also pretty good and round out the album very well.  I would put this as the second best Rush album, behind 2112, but it might be a little more accessible to casual listeners.
